The first program (Track 1) contains Mary Click and Zeb Robinson singing "When the Roses Bloom in Dixieland," Gene Jenkins playing the guitar, Sunshine Sue singing "Maple on the Hill," Mary Click, Zeb Robinson, and Irving Gurganus accompanied by Sonny Day and Gene Jenkins singing "A Love that Has Ended Too Soon." The second program (Track 2) contains Irving Gurganus performing "Darby's Ram," Sonny Day playing the accordion, Sunshine Sue singing "I Dreamed of an Old Affair," Sonny Day and Zeb Robinson singing "With These Pins and Needles in My Heart," and Sunshine Sue singing "Where Could I Go." Also includes commercials for Karo Syrup and Niagra Instant Laundry Starch.

did.unittitle: Open for Opinion, 30 November 1961

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Frank Brooks, this listener call-in program features F. Henry Garber III (1910-1979) of Richmond City Council answering questions concerning the proposed merger of Richmond and Henrico County, and explaining why he is opposed to a consolidation.

did.unittitle: Open for Opinion, 5 December 1961

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Frank Brooks, this listener call-in program features Robert P. Buford, III, an attorney from Henrico County and member of "Citizens for Merger," answering questions concerning the proposed merger of Richmond and Henrico County, and explaining why he is in favor of a consolidation.

did.unittitle: Open for Opinion, 5 January 1962

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Frank Brooks, this listener call-in program features a discussion with Governor J. Lindsay Almond (1898-1966). Listeners calls are also taken. Almond talks about his term as governor, the inaugural address of his successor Albertis S. Harrison, his feelings on leaving office, the state's sales tax, the administration of President John F. Kennedy, his greatest accomplishments and biggest disappointments while serving as governor, issues relating to Virginia's ports, public education, Richmond's traffic congestion, factory automation, states' rights, taxes, the Virginia National Guard, the Governor's Mansion, pardons and release of prisoners, the two party system of government, the local option issue, alcohol legislation, Catholic schools, crime and sentencing guidelines, and the exodus of African-Americans from the South. He also discusses his future plans after leaving office.

did.unittitle: Owsley, Alvin Mansfield. Address Before the American Legion State Convention in Richmond, 3 August 1957

scopecontent.p: Address, 3 August 1957, by Alvin M. Owsley (1888-1967) before the American Legion State Convention in Richmond, Virginia. Topics include the importance of the youth in America to carry on the traditions of the Legion, why the United States failed in Korea, his visit to the Virginia War Memorial, states' rights, debates in the U.S. Congress on the trial by jury bill and immigration law, and the need to defeat Communism.

did.unittitle: Panel Discussions on a Proposed Expressway, 1951

scopecontent.p: Panel discussions, 26 October 1951, on the proposed referendum to build an expressway in the city of Richmond. The panelists are in favor of the referendum, and the spots are paid for by "Citizens for Traffic Relief." Issues discussed include the need for a modern freeway, traffic problems in Richmond, congestion, safety issues, property values, taxes, the idea of building a bypass rather than a freeway, alternatives, costs, and the use of federal and state funds for its construction. There are also comments on the referendum's approval roughly a week later, the obstacles that were overcome, and opposition to the plan by various individuals and groups. The recording ends with studio chatter, weather, programming schedule, The Ambassadors' recording of "Yearning," and fashion tips.

did.unittitle: People You Know Miller and Rhoads Audition, 23 February 1944

scopecontent.p: This is an incomplete transcription of the quiz program People You Know, as recorded in the Virginia Room at the Hotel John Marshall. Quiz participants are Rotarians. It is not clear from the recording what the program had to do with Miller and Rhoads.

did.unittitle: The Peter Babalas Affair: Censure of Norfolk State Senator Peter Babalas, 1986

scopecontent.p: Recording of WRVA's entry in the 1986 Virginia Association of Broadcasters news awards competition for best continuing story. The broadcast documents the conflict of interests allegations against State Senator Peter K. Babalas (1922-1987) concerning his vote against legislation that involved Landbank Equity Corporation, one of his private law firm clients. Included are stories on the opinions of the Senate Ethics Advisory Panel and the state attorney general, legislative proposals on conflict of interests by the Virginia General Assembly, Babalas' trial and acquittal, and his eventual censure by the State Senate.

did.unittitle: Poage Concedes to Gary, 2 November 1948

scopecontent.p: Recording of the broadcast of the concession speech of Richard C. Poage, Republican candidate for the Third Congressional district in Virginia in 1948. Poage concedes the election to his Democratic opponent, J. Vaughan Gary, and hopes that his campaign furthered two-party politics in Virginia.

did.unittitle: Pocahontas Fuel Company Mine Explosion Report, 27 October 1958

scopecontent.p: Report, 27 October, 1958, on a methane gas explosion at a mine in Bishop, West Virginia operated by the Pocahontas Fuel Company. The explosion resulted in the deaths of 22 workers, and occurred underground almost directly under the Virginia/West Virginia state line.

did.unittitle: Portrait to Lieutenant Governor Collins, 15 February 1954

scopecontent.p: State Senator Ted Dalton speaks at the unveiling of the portrait of Lieutenant Governor L. Preston "Pat" Collins (1896-1952) in the Virginia State Senate on 15 February 1954. Dalton calls Collins' death on 20 September 1952 a loss for both parties.

did.unittitle: President Eisenhower Places Wreath on Mary Washington's Grave, 9 May 1954

scopecontent.p: Recording of the broadcast of the ceremony surrounding President Eisenhower's placing of a wreath on Mary Washington's grave on Mother's Day, 9 May 1954. Includes music from the United States Marine Corps Band of Quantico, Virginia and the Fredericksburg Civic Choir, speeches from Gertrude S. Carraway (1896-1993) and Frances Mason Williams, and brief words from President Eisenhower. Carraway delivered a speech entitled "George Washington's Greatest Inspiration," his mother, Mary Ball Washington. Williams speaks on the history of the Mary Washington Memorial. Eisenhower states how honored he is to have the privilege of paying tribute to Mary Washington and praises George Washington's character. Don Vest reported for WRVA.

did.unittitle: President Eisenhower's Visit to Richmond, 9 May 1954

scopecontent.p: Recording of President Eisenhower's visit to Richmond on Mother's Day, 9 May 1954. George Passage, Herb Clarke, and Harry Monroe of WRVA News report on Eisenhower's visit from his arrival at Byrd Airport to his attendance at Mother's Day services at St. Paul's Episcopal Church. Includes a discussion of the anniversary of the Richmond Light Infantry Blues, a listing of other militia units in Richmond to celebrate the anniversary, and a description of the history and interior of St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

did.unittitle: Price, James H., Speech, 22 November 1940

scopecontent.p: Recording of speech of Governor James H. Price on 22 November 1940 in Staunton, Virginia. Price outlines his legislative plan for changing the administrative structure of state government, probation and parole, the deplorable conditions of local jails, elimination of the fee system, the establishment of a modern personnel system, road building, passage of workers' compensation law, electoral reforms, repeal of the poll tax, increased teachers' salaries, and improved funding for schools. Recording is incomplete.

did.unittitle: Program of the Dedication of WRVA's New 50,000 Watt Transmitter, 17 March 1939

scopecontent.p: Broadcast of the dedication of WRVA's new 50,00 watt transmitter on 17 March 1939. Program included music, congratulatory words from WRVA's national affiliate, CBS, Governor James H. Price, and Senator Harry F. Byrd, information on the establishment of WRVA, highlights of WRVA's broadcasting history, and a description of the new transmitter from its site on the James River in eastern Henrico County, Virginia. Produced by CBS, the program goes back and forth between New York and Richmond.

did.unittitle: Puller, Chesty, Speech, 24 July 1959
did.physdesc: 1 compact disc. Duration: 1 hr., 7 min., 36 sec.

scopecontent.p: Speech, 24 July 1959, of Chesty Puller, retired Marine Lieutenant General. Puller expresses his opinions on a variety of subjects including American diplomacy, the military preparedness of the United States, and increased taxation. The recordings should be listened to in the following order: WRVA - 361, track 1 (side I); WRVA - 362, track 2 (side IV); WRVA - 361, track 3 (side III); and WRVA - 361, track 2 (side II).

did.unittitle: Queen Elizabeth, Williamsburg, Virginia, 16 October 1957

scopecontent.p: Jack Clements reports on the visit of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip to the College of William and Mary during their tour of Tidewater Virginia, during the 350th anniversary celebration of the founding of Jamestown. From the balcony of the campus' Christopher Wren Building, the Queen and Prince appear and are welcomed by James M. Robertson, Rector of the Board of Visitors of the College of William and Mary. He comments on the historic relationship between the British Royal Crown and education in Virginia, beginning with the chartering of the college in 1693, and notes this is the first visit to the college by a reigning monarch of Great Britain. The Queen presents a gift of a copy of the Statute of the Order of the Garter, presented to Prince William, Duke of Gloucester, nephew of King William, three years after the founding of the College. Prince Philip is greeted by Alvin Duke Chandler, President of the College of William and Mary, and the two exchange gifts between the College and the University of Edinburgh, the alma mater of the College's first president, the Reverend James Blair.

did.unittitle: Quiz of Two Cities, 17 April 1948

scopecontent.p: Recorded on 17 April 1948 in Richmond and Norfolk, this quiz show features employees of the Virginia Transit Company in both cities answering questions in various categories. Art Richardson is the announcer. Alden Aaroe is the host in Richmond, and Ira Hull hosts from Norfolk.

did.unittitle: Quiz of Two Cities, 26 July 1948

scopecontent.p: Recorded in Richmond and Norfolk, this quiz show features employees of the Graybar Electric Company in both cities answering questions in various categories. Art Richardson is the announcer. Alden Aaroe is the host in Richmond, and Bob Knapp hosts from Norfolk.

did.unittitle: Quiz of Two States, 9 November 1946

scopecontent.p: A general quiz show matching wits between members of various groups or organizations from Richmond and Charlotte, North Carolina. This particular episode presents the Richmond Lions Club and the Charlotte, N.C., Lions Club. The North Carolina portion of the program was broadcast from Charlotte's station WBT. "Quiz Wizards" Scott Jarrett for the Richmond team and Kurt Webster for the Charlotte participants ask their respective teams the questions. Listerine is the sponsor of this program.

did.unittitle: Radio Scholarship Quiz, 1952-1955, 1957-1958
did.physdesc: 17 compacts discs. Duration: 8 hrs., 28 min., 23 sec.

scopecontent.p: Recordings of the quiz show "Radio Scholarship Quiz," sponsored by WRVA and the University of Richmond and covering the years 1952 to 1955, and 1957 to 1958. Dean Raymond B. Pinchbeck (1900-1957) of Richmond College was the first quizmaster. Dean C. J. Gray (1908-2003) took over the duties in later programs. Students from various Virginia high schools compete against each other for a chance to win various cash prizes, including an all-expense paid one-year scholarship to Richmond College or Westhampton College. The students are introduced, and they discuss their backgrounds, school activities, and future plans. They alternate answering questions in the categories of history, spelling, English, mathematics, science, and literature. The competitions took place at high schools in Brunswick and Spotsylvania Counties, Fredericksburg, Hampton, Highland Springs, Hopewell, Midlothian, Newport News, Norfolk, Petersburg, Richmond, and Williamsburg.

did.unittitle: Reed, William T. , Jr., Statement on the 25th Anniversary of WRVA, 1 November 1950

scopecontent.p: Statement, 1 November 1950, by William T. Reed, Jr. (1904-1966), president of Larus and Brother Company, on the 25th anniversary of WRVA. Reed recognizes the assistance of the Federal Radio and Communications Commission, the Columbia Broadcasting System, and the support of the station's listeners. He also discusses the station's plans for television broadcasting in the future.

did.unittitle: Religious Service Commemorating the 250th Anniversary of the Bruton Parish Church Building, 14 November 1965
did.physdesc: 2 compact discs. Duration: 1 hr., 26 min., 46 sec.

scopecontent.p: Religious service held at Bruton Parish Church in Williamsburg, Virginia on 14 November 1965, commemorating the 250th anniversary of the completion of the church building. The commemorative sermon was delivered by Bishop John Elbridge Hines (1910-1997), presiding bishop of the National Episcopal Church.

did.unittitle: Repine, Burt T., "A New Love Every Spring," 18 November 1952

scopecontent.p: Contains "A New Love Every Spring," a song performed by WRVA employee Burt T. Repine (1901-1990) on 18 November 1952.

did.unittitle: Richmond Ballet Promotional Spots

scopecontent.p: Promotional spots for the Richmond Ballet. The dates of the advertisements are unknown. There are four different spots, each announcing upcoming performances, times, ticket outlet locations, and guest artists.

did.unittitle: Richmond Celebration of Turnpike Opening, 30 June 1958

scopecontent.p: This disc contains recordings of the ceremonies held in celebration of the opening of the Richmond-Petersburg Turnpike on 30 June 1958. These are the full-length recordings made for an episode of Sideviews on the News, and Jack Clements is the host. Speakers at the ceremonies include T. Coleman Andrews, president of the Richmond Chamber of Commerce, who talks about the safety features of this "dream of modern transportation"; F. Henry Garber, mayor of Richmond, who discusses the turnpike's impact on retail and civic relations between Richmond, Petersburg, Hopewell and other communities; former Governor Thomas Stanley; and Governor J. Lindsay Almond.

did.unittitle: Richmond Junior Chamber of Commerce Rally, 1 October 1957

scopecontent.p: Rally, held on 1 October 1957, by the Richmond Junior Chamber of Commerce. Highlights include speeches by Virginia gubernatorial candidates Ted Dalton (1901-1989) and J. Lindsay Almond (1898-1986), and their comments concerning the Supreme Court decision on school desegregation, civil rights legislation, Little Rock, the pupil assignment plan in Virginia, the admission of African-American students into North Carolina colleges, and that state's assignment plan.

did.unittitle: Richmond Memorial Hospital Dedication, 13 January 1957

scopecontent.p: Dedication, 13 November 1957, of Richmond Memorial Hospital in Richmond, Virginia. Speakers include Robert E. Henley, president of the hospital's Board of Trustees, Richmond Mayor F. Henry Garber, Virginia State Treasurer Jesse W. Dillon, and Emma Gray Trigg. There is also music by the Union Theological Seminary choir, and the invocation and benediction is given by Reverend Theodore F. Adams, pastor of the First Baptist Church in Richmond.

did.unittitle: Richmond Newspapers Marathon Coverage, 23 October 1988

scopecontent.p: Coverage of the Richmond Newspapers marathon held on 23 October 1988, featuring clips from various reporters during the 26-mile run through downtown Richmond.

did.unittitle: Richmond Report on Who Killed Michael Farmer, 21 April 1958

scopecontent.p: Jack Clements hosts this program addressing the local juvenile delinquency situation. Other participants are Mr. Carroll Minor, Director of Youth Services at the State Department of Welfare; Sergeant Robert P. Milliken, Juvenile and Missing Persons Division of the Richmond Police Bureau; and Sydney G. Morton, Intake Officer at the Richmond Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court. The program aired immediately following a CBS radio documentary hosted by Edward R. Murrow called "Who Killed Michael Farmer?" Farmer was a teenager who was killed in New York City by a youth gang from the Bronx. The participants discuss the depth of the problems of violence and juvenile crime and delinquency in Richmond as compared to New York City. They look for reasons for the problems, including race relations, mobility of population, density of population, television and family situations.

did.unittitle: Richmond School Board Chairman Response to Complaints of the Richmond Education Association, [1993]

scopecontent.p: Response by the chairman of the Richmond School Board to the vote of "no confidence" and resolution passed by the Richmond Education Association (R.E.A). The exact date of the recording is unknown, but assumed to be in 1993. The chairman responds to the R.E.A.'s attacks on the school board's leadership, low teacher raises and pay disparity, and demands for an elected school board. In their resolution, the R.E.A. also addressed the following issues: upgrades and reclassification of support personnel, student discipline problems, planning and initiatives by the Board, lack of attention paid to the R.E.A., the budget proposed for 1993-1994, and grievance procedures.

did.unittitle: Robert Beadles News, 1 July 1929

scopecontent.p: Includes reports on President Hoover urging passage of farm relief and tariff legislation before Congress, as well as other national news and a stock market report. Also covered is John Archer Lejuene becoming the new superintendent of the Virginia Military Institute, opening of the baseball season, churches in the U.S. experiencing gains in membership, and conditions at a Richmond orphanage.

did.unittitle: Robert, Joseph C., Address at the Inauguration of Dr. Robert Blackwell Smith, Jr., as President of the Medical College of Virginia, 17 December 1956

scopecontent.p: Address, 17 December 1956, by Dr. Joseph C. Robert (1906-2003), president of Hampden-Sydney College, at the inauguration of Dr. Robert Blackwell Smith, Jr., as fourth president of the Medical College of Virginia. Dr. Robert discusses the history of MCV from its founding, medical practices in the nineteenth century, school requirements and course work, and the college's affiliation with Hampden-Sydney College. The recording ends with the swearing in of Dr. Smith.

did.unittitle: Romulo, Carlos P., Commencement Speech at the University of Richmond, 5 June 1956

scopecontent.p: Contains the speech of Carlos P. Romulo to the University of Richmond graduation class of 1956. Romulo invokes the name of Thomas Jefferson and the importance of Jeffersonian principles for countries whose people are oppressed. He stresses the importance of choosing between freedom and Soviet imperialism.

did.unittitle: Romulo, Carlos P., Speech Before the 51st Annual Convention of the Virginia Education Association, 1 November 1957
did.physdesc: 1 compact disc. Duration: 1 hr., 2 min., 29 sec.

scopecontent.p: Speech, 1 November 1957, by Carlos P. Romulo (1899-1985), Philippines ambassador to the United States, before the Virginia Education Association. Romulo is introduced by Virginia Congressman J. Vaughan Gary (1892-1973). In his speech entitled "The Asia America Does Not Know," Romulo comments on the importance of Asia to U.S. national security, discusses Soviet imperialism and that country's incursions into Formosa, Korea, the Philippines, Greece, China, and India, and urges the U.S. to continue to build strong friendships with other countries to combat the Soviet's "desire of world conquest."

did.unittitle: Ronald H. Conway Press Conference, 10 November 1961

scopecontent.p: Press conference, 10 November 1961, with Ronald H. Conway, captain and pilot of the Imperial Airlines jet that crashed near Byrd Field in Richmond, Virginia on 8 November 1961. The jet, a Lockheed L-049E Constellation, went down at night in a wooded area, enroute from Newark, New Jersey to Columbia, South Carolina via Baltimore, resulting in the deaths of 77 passengers. There were two survivors. Conway recounts his actions, and the actions of the crew and passengers, before and after the crash, before various reporters at the Medical College of Virginia Hospital. The taped comments are introduced by Lon Backman of WRVA.

did.unittitle: S.S. United States Launching, 16 May 1952

scopecontent.p: WRVA reports from the S.S. United States, an ocean liner built at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company in Newport News, Virginia, on its first trial run. The broadcast covers the ocean liner's background and its amenities, discusses the system used to measure the liner's speed, and includes interviews of random attendees of the event. The S.S. United States is expected to beat the speed record held by the British liner, Queen Mary.

did.unittitle: Safety Award, 11 September 1947

scopecontent.p: Recording of the presentation of a certificate of achievement to WRVA for its public service announcements on behalf of safety on Virginia's highways. C. T. Lucy, WRVA General Managers accepts the certificate from Governor William M. Tuck and speaks briefly on WRVA's support for the community. William R. Wilson thanks his radio colleagues, WRVA management, and state officials for their efforts in making Virginia's highways safer. Aired 14 September 1947.

did.unittitle: St. George Story, Bermuda's Part in the Jamestown Story, 16 February 1957

scopecontent.p: Re-enactment of the voyage of the Sea Venture, from its departure in England in June 1609 to its wreck in Bermuda after a hurricane and the settlement of Bermuda. Also includes a description of Bermuda's historic sites and its history from the settlement through the Civil War, and a ceremony featuring the Governor of Bermuda and Lieutenant-Governor of Virginia, A.E.S Stephens. The ceremony includes the dedication of a plaque commemorating the wreck of the Sea Venture and the voyage of the ships, Patience and Deliverance, built by the shipwrecked crew of the Sea Venture and sailed to Jamestown in May 1610 bringing much needed supplies, and a speech of Lieutenant Governor Stephens accepting replicas of the Patience and Deliverance.

did.unittitle: St. Paul's Polytechnic Institute Songs, 15 December 1953

scopecontent.p: The St. Paul's Polytechnic Institute (renamed St. Paul's College in February 1957) choir of Lawrenceville, Virginia, sing Christmas carols.

did.unittitle: Saturday Session with Lyle Bradley, 29 April 1957

scopecontent.p: Features popular music selections, including "40 Cups of Coffee" by Les Brown and JoAnne Greer, "Yeah, Yeah, Yeah" by the Ames Brothers, "A Shoulder to Cry On" by Susan Silo, "Love Me a Little Bit" by Eddy Howard, "Music Maestro Please" by the Tommy Dorsey Orchestra, "I Thought it was Over" by Frank Duval and Orchestra, "Dispy-Doodle" by Larry Clinton, "Bumble Bee" by Doris Day, and "Street of Dreams" by the Tommy Dorsey Orchestra. There is also a weather forecast, a commercial for Budweiser, and a public service announcement for free chest x-rays being offered in Richmond. The show cuts off in mid-song.

did.unittitle: Second Honeymoon: Governor's Highway Safety Committee. Program 3, 1947

scopecontent.p: Drama concerning an accident between a train and an automobile. Includes graphic description of the accident's carnage. The driver of the automobile had been drinking and was driving too fast. He tried to race the train and created a horrific accident. Program was based on a true accident. Written by Charles Freeman. Produced by Dan Valentine. This recording is track 1 on WRVA - 337.

did.unittitle: Search for Lost Boys, 13 August 1953

scopecontent.p: News reports on the search for four lost boys, Walter Charles "Tex" Boykin, age 7, twin brothers, Wilson and Woodrow Blackstock, age 7, and their brother, George Blackstock, age 5. Alden Aaroe reports on the search for the boys direct from the scene in the McGuire Hospital area of Chesterfield County. John Tansey reports on the discovery of the boy's bodies in an abandoned icebox near their homes (8:06).

did.unittitle: Sheppard, Eleanor P., Interview, 12 July 1962

scopecontent.p: Interview, 12 July 1962, with Eleanor P. Sheppard (1907-1991), shortly after her election as mayor of Richmond, Virginia. She discusses her feelings about family and children, comments on her duties as mayor, and gives her opinions regarding a woman being elected president of the United States.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: 30th Anniversary Luncheon for Brotherhood Week, 19 February 1956

scopecontent.p: This program concerns the 30th anniversary luncheon for Brotherhood Week, containing excerpts of a speech by Dr. Lewis Webster Jones (1899-1975), president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, and a speech by Walter W. Craigie, Sr., regarding the creation of a community award to give to those advancing the cause of brotherhood. John Tansey accepts the award on behalf of WRVA for its role in raising money for the Crippled Children's Hospital. Samuel E. Binswanger also received a certificate for promoting brotherhood among all people. This program also includes commercials for the Raleigh Grill on 9th and Bank Street and Wright's Townhouse at 513 E. Grace Street.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News, 27 May 1957

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Jack Clements, this show includes a special feature, news, weather, and commercial spots. The special feature in this broadcast is on polygraph machines, including how they work, accuracy, and results, as explained by a representative from a Richmond detective agency. News stories include the Virginia attorney general campaign, the death of former House of Delegate member Howard C. Rogers of Loudoun County, Korean War preparedness, state automobile accidents, updates on the Pupil Placement Act in Virginia and civil rights legislation in the U.S. Congress, including comments by Sen. A. Willis Robertson, the mutual test ban treaty in the U.S. Congress, foreign aid requests, and U.S. Navy strength. There are commercial spots for Ford Motors, Metropolitan Life, Supersuds detergent, Budweiser, and Camel cigarettes.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Anniversary of Lee's Surrender, 18 April 1956

scopecontent.p: Includes speech of Douglas Southall Freeman from 1950 dedicating the restoration of the Wilmer McLean house at Appomattox. Freeman describes the surrender and the reaction of Confederate soldiers to the surrender, and compares the appearances of Lee and Grant. Also contains Jack Clements reading a poem from Percy Gregg, a British historian and southern sympathizer, written in 1865.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News, 26 January 1963

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Larry Dodd, this show features an interview with Frank W. Berkman, executive vice-president of the Hotel Sales Management Association. Berkman discusses the purpose and history of the organization, founded in 1927, its convention activities, and the organization of the Virginia chapter. The organization is now known as Hospitality Sales and Marketing Association International.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Bermuda, 28 March 1958

scopecontent.p: Ray Kennedy hosts this episode of Sideviews on the News, in which Jack Clements reports from his visit to Bermuda. He provides a basic overview of the locale, including the geography, population, climate and history.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Birth Control, 14 December 1959

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Lon Backman, this show features interviews with Reverend Anthony Zimmerman and Dr. John R. Cavanagh, who discuss the Catholic Church's views on birth control and overpopulation.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Captain Jack Pettis, 30 July 1956

scopecontent.p: Jack Clements interviews Jack Pettis (John Powell Pettis), retired captain of the Virginia Capitol Police. Pettis was appointed to the Capitol Police in 1889 by then-Governor Fitzhugh Lee. He retired in 1948 under Governor William M. Tuck. Pettis reminiscences about his years working at the state capitol, commenting on various governors, politics, and the capitol grounds. He considered E. Lee Trinkle the friendliest governor and Andrew Jackson Montague the most colorful. This recording is Track 1 on WRVA - 147.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Chesapeake and Potomac Series, 27 January-15 February 1958

scopecontent.p: Jack Clements hosts this four part series of Sideviews on the News detailing the daily operations and inner workings of the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company of Virginia. The program is co-hosted by Mr. C. E. Grosser from the Virginia Society of Professional Engineers. The purpose of the program is to promote an interest in engineering as a career opportunity for Virginia high school students.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Chesty Puller, 24 July 1959

scopecontent.p: Contains a recap of the highlights of Chesty Puller's speech on WRVA 361-362. This recording is track 2 on WRVA - 362.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Christmas at the Governor's Mansion with Mrs. Albertis S. Harrison, [1962]

scopecontent.p: Brick Rider and his children, Mark and Nanette, take a tour of the Governor's Mansion at Christmas time with Mrs. Lacey Virginia (Barkley) Harrison. The children tell Mrs. Harrison what they want for Christmas. Rider and Mrs. Harrison talk about the Mansion, discussing its decorations, the number of rooms, the portraits, and the cleaning of the chandeliers.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Christmas at the Governor's Mansion with Mrs. Stanley, 23 December 1957

scopecontent.p: Jack Clements, WRVA news editor and his daughter, Ann, visit the Governor's Mansion at Christmas time. Ann describes the mansion's Christmas tree. Anne Pocahontas (Bassett) Stanley describes the trees, decorations, and Christmas at the Governor's Mansion.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Christmas Eve, 1956-1957

scopecontent.p: Jack Clements hosts this edition of Sideviews on the News, in which he goes to the North Pole to investigate rumors that Santa Claus will be unable to deliver his toys due to the fact the Rudolph's red nose is not working. The supposed cause of the problem is the commercialization of Christmas, and the program is intended to remind people of the religious basis of the holiday. WRVA-622 is the 1956 broadcast of this story, and WRVA-623 is the same story but from 1957.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Colonel Wright, New Chief of Police, 24 February 1961

scopecontent.p: Lon Backman hosts this episode of Sideviews on the News, in which he interviews John Wright, the new chief of police for the city of Richmond. Wright, who had been on the force forty-one years at the time of his appointment, joined the force at age 18 and served as acting chief for nearly a year. Backman asks him about his plans for the force, what the previous year as acting chief was like and the response of his wife to his new position.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Dean Raymond B. Pinchbeck Tribute, 4 February 1957

scopecontent.p: This program is a tribute to Raymond B. Pinchbeck (1900-1957), Dean at the University of Richmond, professor of economics, and host of WRVA's Radio Scholarship Quiz, who died on 4 February 1957. Includes reminiscences of and tributes to Pinchbeck from Carl Stutz, Ray Kennedy, and Walter R. Bishop, all employees of WRVA Radio. Stutz reminiscences about his years as one of Pinchbeck's students at the University of Richmond. Kennedy shares his memories working with Pinchbeck on the Radio Scholarship Quiz Show. Bishop recounts Pinchbeck's civic achievements and public service. Also includes a news tribute and excerpts from Pinchbeck's talk on the national radio broadcast, "This I Believe."

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Egypt-Arab League, 13 February 1958

scopecontent.p: Jack Clements hosts a discussion with a former dean from the School of Commerce at Cairo University about the League of Arab States, also commonly known as the Arab League. His guest defines the organization and comments that this goodwill tour of the United States is an effort to win friends for Egypt. He talks about the importance of the unity of Arab states, while Clements asks him questions about the relationship between the communists and the Arab states, how the Egyptians feel about Americans, the issue of Israel and where Egypt would stand if there was a war between the United States and Russia. His guest comments on the instance following the Civil War in which approximately fifty Confederate officers from Virginia went to Egypt to help them build their army.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Enterprise Special Merger Annexation, [1960]

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Lon Backman, this show features four different programs devoted to the issue of annexation of Henrico County by the City of Richmond. The date of the programs are not known, but thought to be from 1960. Backman interviews various individuals involved in the annexation/consolidation controversy. Horace Edwards, Richmond City Manager, discusses the annexation ordinance process, various studies taking place, court procedures, annexation case questions, costs involved, referendum procedures, and statewide trends in annexation cases. A. Howe Todd, executive director of the Richmond Regional Planning Commission, talks about the work and composition of the Commission, the merger/annexation process, tax issues, differences between annexation and merger, and the work of the Public Administration Service (PAS). Richmond City Councilman J. Edward Lawler explains the issues involved, tax burden, business tax revenues in the city vs. county tax revenues, who would benefit from annexation, the chances of annexation succeeding, the resolution introduced by him on annexation, effect of the recent flood in Richmond on the issue, and race and school issues and their effect on the proposal. Joseph T. Williams, Jr., a member of the Virginia House of Delegates, states his position on the issue and why is vehemently opposed to annexation, discusses his legislative work in the General Assembly on the topic, and how issues of race could affect the question of annexation. Burl A. Parks, director of city planning, sums up the issues involved in annexation, merger, and status quo. Parks discusses what the alternatives are, forms of government, services provided, and tax issues involved in all three options.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Hawaii Elections, 6 August 1959

scopecontent.p: 1 compact disc. Lon Backman, WRVA news broadcaster, reports on the first free elections in Hawaii. Includes sound bytes of radio broadcasts concerning the elections from Station KGU-AM in Honolulu.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Hungarian General, 18 February 1960

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Jack Clements, this show features an interview with Bela K. Kiraly, leader of the Hungarian resistance movement. Kiraly discusses the struggle by the resistance against the Soviet army in his country in 1956, and also the role of Radio Free Europe in combating Communism.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Interview with C. T. Overstreet, 23 August 1962

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Joe Lowen, this show features an interview with Carson Thomas Overstreet (1901-2000) of Glen Allen, Virginia concerning the possible defection of his "foster" son James Joseph Dresnok to North Korea. Overstreet discusses Dresnock's childhood, divorce, prior military service, and what he has learned from the U.S. military concerning Dresnok's disappearance while serving in the Army in South Korea near the demilitarized zone.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Juvenile Series, 15 November 1957

scopecontent.p: Jack Clements hosts this three part series of Sideviews on the News, which explores the issue of juvenile crime and delinquency in Richmond. The first part features a discussion of this "serious problem in Richmond" with Kermit V. Rocke, associate judge of the Richmond Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court. Clements asks Rocke his opinions on juvenile delinquency in Richmond as compared to other cities in the country and what he thinks the root causes are for the problem. Part two features an interview with the Reverend Paul Edward Crandall, executive secretary of the Richmond Baptist Association, on what the churches are doing to meet the problem of juvenile crime; and part three features three student guests from John Marshall High School, who also share their opinions and views on the causes and possible solutions to juvenile delinquency in the city.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Leaves and Lives, 30 August 1965

scopecontent.p: This show features Ray Turner reading a poem entitled "Leaves and Lives," about a walk through Maymont Park in Richmond and how the seasons of the year relate to the seasons of one's life.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Mental Discussions, 10-12 August 1959

scopecontent.p: Lon Backman and Jack Clements, WRVA news reporters, explore the issues and problems with the state mental hospitals in a series of five programs. Part 1 contains a discussion with a patient at Western State Hospital and with Dr. Howard H. Ashbury, clinical director of psychology at Western State Hospital, regarding the patient's prognosis. Part 2 contains an interview with Dr. James B. Pettis, superintendent of Western State Hospital, who recounts the history of Western State Hospital and the state of affairs in Virginia's mental hospitals. Also includes an interview with one of the hospital's elderly patients. Part 3 includes a discussion with Dr. Howard H. Ashbury concerning overcrowding. Part 4 contains a discussion with John Edward Raine, chairman of a special legislative commission studying the problems of the aged in Virginia's mental hospitals. Part 5 contains an interview with State Senator Edward Willey, chairman of the Virginia State Hospital Board.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Mr. O'Neal Prevention of Blindness

scopecontent.p: Lon Backman hosts this episode of Sideviews on the News, in which he interviews James E. O'Neal, the director of Industrial Service for the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness. The focus of the interview is the use of industrial safety spectacles with shatter resistant lenses as safer for people than wearing regular glasses when playing sports, doing industrial jobs, fishing, hunting or mowing the lawn. O'Neal also talks specifically about the work of the Industrial Service section of the society and the importance of eye protection to prevent or eliminate unnecessary eye damage. The date of this program is unknown.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Police Series, 1956-1957
did.physdesc: 5 compacts discs. Duration: 2 hrs., 49 min., 51 sec.

scopecontent.p: Covering the period 4 October 1956 through 4 April 1957 and hosted by Jack Clements. This program includes fifteen parts in the series detailing the duties and responsibilities of the Richmond Police Department. Included are shows discussing the Juvenile, Records and Communications, and Traffic Safety Divisions, interviews with police officers while on patrol, coverage of the booking of a suspect and the various procedures that are followed, coverage of a vice-squad raid, discussions on safecrackers, pick-pockets, shoplifters, and automobile thieves, a demonstration of a speed radar, on-the-scene reports of routine traffic stops, as well as a tour of the Richmond Police Academy which includes a discussion on the training of new officers, and the future outlook for the police profession.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Robert E. Lee's Birthday, 18 January 1957

scopecontent.p: This program is recorded in the Virginia Room of the White House of the Confederacy on the occasion of Robert E. Lee's birthday. Walter Bishop, WRVA public relations director, and Jack Clements, WRVA news editor, interview India Thomas, house regent of the Museum of the Confederacy. She discusses the life of Robert E. Lee and the various artifacts of Lee the museum owns. Also includes a speech of Governor Thomas B. Stanley during which he praises Lee and his effort to preserve states' rights.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Robert Heberle, 11 May 1960

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Lon Backman, this show featured Robert J. Heberle (1907-1975), a lawyer and member of Richmond City Council. Heberle discusses his background, outside interests, career, and his interest in the oversight of Richmond's city budget and real estate tax issues.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Rock and Roll, 17 March 1958

scopecontent.p: In this episode of the regular WRVA program, Sideviews on the News, Jack Clements interviews Richmond city police Sergeant Robert Milliken from the Juvenile and Missing Persons Division. The topic is Rock and Roll, "the new music." The discussion revolves around live rock and roll shows and their influence on juvenile delinquency. While the officer concedes that an incident involving six juveniles from the prior evening was not caused by a show at the Mosque, he does say that often the music does incite the youngsters to "get uncontrollable and go into a frenzied state."

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Sales Tax, Senator Byrd, 28 January 1960

scopecontent.p: Lon Backman hosts this segment of Sideviews on the News, in which Senator Harry F. Byrd, Jr., reacts to Governor Almond's comment that his proposed state budget is "bare bones." Byrd discusses the 33.8 percent proposed increase in state expenditures and the 3 percent sales tax bill Almond recommends. Also covered is the possible budget surplus, which at the time had the potential of being the second highest in Virginia history.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Senator A. Willis Robertson, 25-27 October 1961

scopecontent.p: This is a recording of a three-part Sideviews on the News program featuring United States Senator A. Willis Robertson of Virginia. Robertson provides a viewpoint on the "political philosophies, moral philosophies and an assessment of the physical realities in our world today." This includes his feelings about serving as a United States Senator, the United Nations and the United States' responsibility to that body, the attitudes of Americans in the tense times of fears about communism, and states' rights. Hosted by Harry Monroe. This recording is the broadcast version. The original interview between Harry Monroe and Senator Robertson is on WRVA - 230.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Senator Robertson and Hank [Harry] Monroe Original Interview, 27 October 1961

scopecontent.p: Harry (Hank) Monroe, WRVA broadcaster, interviews United States Senator A. Willis Robertson (1887-1971) of Virginia. Robertson reminisces about his tenure in the Virginia state legislature, and talks about his current workload in the U.S. Senate, federal government interference and bureaucracy, military appropriations, U.S.-Soviet relations and the Cold War, the federal deficit, inflation, the Berlin crisis, the United Nations, and the faith of the citizens of the United States in their country. This recording is the original interview conducted. For the broadcast version see WRVA - 541.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Special Turnpike Ceremonies, 30 June 1958

scopecontent.p: This compact disc contains a special episode of Sideviews on the News, covering the ceremonies held in celebration of the opening of the Richmond-Petersburg Turnpike on 30 June 1958. This is an edited version of the full-length recordings contained on WRVA -311. Jack Clements is the host. Speakers at the ceremonies include T. Coleman Andrews, president of the Richmond Chamber of Commerce, who talks about the safety features of this "dream of modern transportation"; F. Henry Garber, mayor of Richmond, who discusses the turnpike's impact on retail and civic relations between Richmond, Petersburg, Hopewell and other communities; former Governor Thomas Stanley; and Governor J. Lindsay Almond.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Steel Strike, 16 July 1959

scopecontent.p: 1 compact disc. Lon Backman, WRVA news reporter, examines the nationwide steel strike and its potential impact on Richmond and Virginia.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News - Tredegar Iron Works, 30 April - 2 May 1957

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Jack Clements, this program includes three segments on the Tredegar Iron Works in Richmond, Virginia. The shows were recorded live at the Tredegar company site, and include a tour of the facilities, history of the company, information on the types of products produced and methods employed, and the future of the company. Interviews are conducted with Edward H. Trigg (1893-1975), vice-president of Tredegar, and Christian E. Grosser (1909-1983), chief engineer at Philip Morris.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Tribute to Robert E. Lee, 21 January 1958

scopecontent.p: Recording of a eulogy of Robert E. Lee delivered on the floor of the Virginia House of Delegates by Delegate E. Ralph James of Hampton. Also includes Jack Clements, WRVA news editor and host of Sideviews on the News, discussing the first American victory in the War of 1812 at the site of present day Talladega, Alabama.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Valentine's Day; Capitol Hotel Fire, 14 February 1958

scopecontent.p: This edition of Sideviews on the News is the Valentine's Day special, featuring a discussion of the historical writings pertaining to love and the holiday. Jack Clements is the host. Included are quotes from the likes of Cicero, Napoleon, John Keats, Robert and Elizabeth Barrett Browning, and Victor Hugo. Also included are other historical tidbits and facts about the holiday. This part of the recording is approximately 9 minutes. The second part of the recording is dedicated to two minutes of news coverage of a fire at the Capitol Hotel, near Grace Street between 8th and 9th streets.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Veterans Day, 11 November 1958

scopecontent.p: Frank Wilson hosts this episode of Sideviews on the News. The report provides a historic overview of the anniversary of the armistice of 1918. Includes clips of President Franklin Delano Roosevelt speaking on the holiday in 1941, as well as Dwight D. Eisenhower speaking at a ceremony honoring the unknown dead from World War II and the Korean War in the spring of 1958.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Virginia General Assembly Public Hearings on School Legislation, 5-6 Sept. 1956

scopecontent.p: This program covers the Virginia General Assembly's public hearings on school legislation. Includes excerpts of statements from people with various views on how Virginia should handle the desegregation issue. The first track contains statements of Delegate J. Randolph Tucker of Richmond, and former Governor Colgate W. Darden supporting the Gray Plan. The second track includes statements from Hal Boyd, president of the Virginia AFL-CIO, opposing the Stanley Plan, Adele Clark calling for some degree of compliance with the Supreme Court decision, Joseph Freehill, Fairfax County Board of Supervisors, explaining that desegregation policy should be set at the state level, Lester Banks, president of the Virginia NAACP, calling for integration at all deliberate speed, and State Senator Edward O. McCue, Jr., of Charlottesville, outlining his plan for handling the segregation issue. The third track includes the statement of J. Segar Gravatt, taking exception to Darden's remark of the day earlier and stating that a course of moderation on the issue is unacceptable.

did.unittitle: Sideviews on the News: Whiskey by the Drink, 27 January 1960

scopecontent.p: Lon Backman hosts this recording of Sideviews on the News. The topic of discussion is a bill introduced into the House of Delegates calling for a local option referendum on serving whiskey and other spirits by the drink. Norfolk delegates Calvin Childress and Henry Howell, the patrons of the bill, are Backman's guests. The basis of the bill was the creation of a new type of liquor license to be administered by the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board to regulate hotels and restaurants serving spirits by the drink. There was a concern that without the passage of this bill, the Tidewater area would suffer due to competition with other Atlantic seaboard resorts unencumbered by laws preventing such sales. Childress and Howell state that this bill would benefit Virginia tourism statewide and would put the decision making on whether to allow such sales in the hands of the people of each locality, rather than the General Assembly. The opposition from some religious groups is also discussed.

did.unittitle: Silver Documentary, 1 November 1950

scopecontent.p: Recording of another program in a series of programs celebrating WRVA's 25th anniversary. Narrated by George Passage and Carl Stutz. Passage and Stutz recount the history of WRVA from its inaugural broadcast in 1925 to 1950 in the context of historical events, including the Depression, the rise of Hitler, King Edward VIII and Wallis Simpson, the Joe Louis-Max Schmeling fight, the Munich Peace Conference, Pearl Harbor, World War II, the dropping of the atomic bomb, and the 1948 Presidential election. Includes sound bytes of various events and personalities.

did.unittitle: Silver Star Quartet, 11 June 1947

scopecontent.p: This installment of the weekly gospel program includes a performance by the Silver Star Quartet's special guests, the Hopewell Jubilee Singers. Songs performed include "When Days are Dark and Friends are Few", "One Day" as performed by the Hopewell Jubilee Singers and "Oh, Lord, when my work on earth is done, I won't duress." Wesley Harvey is the narrator of the program.

did.unittitle: Silver Star Quartet

scopecontent.p: Undated recording of clips of opening and closing segments for the program and background harmonizing by the Silver Star Quartet, which was formed in Richmond, Virginia, in 1932. Originally known as the Gospel Spirituals, the group's performances were first broadcast over the WRVA airwaves in 1939, the weekly program was most often presented at 6:30 a.m. each Sunday morning for over 61 years and had about 20 different members over the years. The last program was broadcast on 8 October 2000.

did.unittitle: Silver Stars Open and Close

scopecontent.p: Undated sound clips of opening and closing segments for the program and background harmonizing by the Silver Star Quartet, which was formed in Richmond, Virginia, in 1932. Originally known as the Gospel Spirituals, the group's performances were first broadcast over the WRVA airwaves in 1939, the weekly program was most often presented at 6:30 a.m. each Sunday morning for over 61 years and had about 20 different members over the years. The last program was broadcast on 8 October 2000.

did.unittitle: Silver Wedding Anniversary, 27 October 1950

scopecontent.p: Recording of an anniversary party for twenty-five couples married in 1925. This program is one of a series of programs celebrating WRVA's 25th anniversary. Hosted by George Passage and Lee Lively. Contains interviews with some of the couples, asking such questions as how they met, when and where they got engaged, and what does she cook for him? Each couple is asked how many business firms were established in 1925, with the winner receiving a second honeymoon at the Cavalier Hotel in Virginia Beach.

did.unittitle: Song Hits of 1925, 27 October 1950

scopecontent.p: Contains music and a look back at early radios and notable events of 1925. Hosted by Carl Stutz and Marc Rogers. Broadcast in celebration of WRVA's 25th anniversary.

did.unittitle: Songs of the Southlanders: WRVA 29th Birthday Special, 31 October 1954

scopecontent.p: Features inspirational music and religious gospel selections. The group's leader talks about their beginnings on WRVA and their upcoming schedule of appearances. Also included on the program is Joseph Matthews and the Sabbath Glee Club from the Fifth Street Baptist Church in Richmond. Walter Bishop interviews Matthews about the group's start on the station, and they perform a rendition of "Swing Low Sweet Chariot."

did.unittitle: Southwest Virginia Flood Coverage, 7 April 1963

scopecontent.p: Coverage, 7 April 1963, of the devastating floods in Southwest Virginia by John Wilson. Wilson reports on the damage, especially around the city of Norton, and interviews a Lion's Club relief worker. Also included is the announcement by Governor Albertis S. Harrison of his disaster area proclamation. Damage to areas in Dickinson, Lee, Tazewell, and Wise Counties is also covered in the broadcast.

did.unittitle: VMI Spirit, 11 September 1959

scopecontent.p: Recording of "Spirit of V.M.I.," the fight song of the Virginia Military Institute, by an unknown performer.

did.unittitle: Spousal Abuse: Ten-Part Documentary, October 1984

scopecontent.p: Ten-part documentary on spousal abuse in the Richmond area, broadcast in October 1984. Includes segments featuring comments by victims and abusers, statistics, reasons for abuse, the effects of television, various forms of assistance available, program funding and the effectiveness of those programs, reporting and documentation of abuse, and recourses for victims.

did.unittitle: Stanley for Governor, 2 November 1953

scopecontent.p: Recording of a statewide broadcast consisting of endorsements for Democratic gubernatorial candidate Thomas B. Stanley, from several prominent Virginians. On WRNL in Richmond, Horace H. Edwards and Watkins M. Abbitt endorse Stanley and praise his experience. Also endorsing Stanley is J. Lindsay Almond, Democratic candidate for attorney general, on WDBJ in Roanoke, and A. E. S. Stephens, Democratic candidate for lieutenant-governor, on WLPM in Suffolk, Virginia. On WMVA in Martinsville, Thomas Stanley criticizes the proposals of the Republican candidate Ted Dalton, notably the $100 million bond issue for roads, and praises Virginia's pay-as-you-go spending philosophy and political ideals. The State Democratic Campaign Committee purchased the air time for the broadcast.

did.unittitle: Stanley, Thomas B., Address to the Virginia General Assembly, 30 November 1955

scopecontent.p: Address, 30 November 1955, by Governor Thomas B. Stanley to the Virginia General Assembly concerning the 1954 United States Supreme Court decision on school desegregation, Virginia's reaction since, and its future course of action. Governor Stanley calls for a constitutional convention for amending of the state's constitution to allow state funds to be appropriated to private schools.

did.unittitle: Stanley, Thomas B., Address to General Assembly, 8 January 1958

scopecontent.p: Recording of the final address of the Governor Stanley to a joint session of the Virginia General Assembly. Stanley reviews the accomplishments of his administration and outlines recommendations for the upcoming General Assembly session. He discusses the desegregation issue and the battle for states' rights.

did.unittitle: Stanley, Thomas B., Announcement Calling for a Special Session of the Virginia General Assembly, 6 June 1956

scopecontent.p: Announcement, 6 June 1956, by Governor Thomas B. Stanley of his intention to call a special session of the Virginia General Assembly to consider recommendations of the Commission on Public Education (Gray Commission) and other public school issues following the 1954 United States Supreme Court decision on school desegregation.

did.unittitle: Stanley, Thomas B., Governor Stanley on Little Rock, 26 September 1957

scopecontent.p: Governor Thomas B. Stanley explains his views on President Eisenhower sending troops into Little Rock to enforce court-ordered integration. He considers Eisenhower's action the biggest blow to the South since Reconstruction and calls it a violation of states' rights. He criticizes the Supreme Court lead by Chief Justice Earl Warren for legislating rather than interpreting the United States Constitution.

did.unittitle: Stanley, Thomas B., Governor Stanley Segregation, 17 May 954

scopecontent.p: Recording of Governor Thomas B. Stanley's initial response to the United States Supreme Court decision in Brown v. Board of Education in which the court declared segregated schools unconstitutional. Stanley called for "cool heads,calm study, and sound judgment" and planned to meet with leaders of both races to consider plans "in keeping with the edict of the court."

did.unittitle: Stanley, Thomas B., Inaugural Address, 21 January 1954

scopecontent.p: Recording of the inaugural address of Thomas B. Stanley during which he outlines his legislative plans and budget proposals. Despite a campaign pledge of no new taxes, Stanley calls for an increase to the gasoline tax.

did.unittitle: Stanley, Thomas B., Profile of, 15 January 1958

scopecontent.p: Jack Clements, WRVA news editor, profiles the administration of Governor Thomas B. Stanley from his inauguration and his call for a gasoline tax increase through the Young Turk revolt in the 1954 General Assembly session and the beginning of Massive Resistance to the visit of Queen Elizabeth II to Williamsburg. Includes excerpts of speeches and an evaluation of Stanley's administration by his contemporaries.

did.unittitle: Stanley, Thomas B., Speech Before a Special Session of the Virginia General Assembly, 27 August 1956

scopecontent.p: Speech by Governor Thomas B. Stanley on 27 August 1956 to a special session of the Virginia General Assembly, convened for the purpose of passing the Massive Resistance laws designed to preserve Virginia's system of segregated schools. Calling the issue of integration the gravest problem facing Virginia since 1865, Stanley describes the purpose of the Massive Resistance Laws, commends the work of the Commission on Public Education, refers to the Interposition resolution the General Assembly passed in Feb. 1956, and outlines Virginia's reaction to the Supreme Court decision of 1954 from the beginning to the present. He declares that he supports full educational attainment for both races and intends to take all honorable, legal, and constitutional means to prevent the usurpation of states' rights.

did.unittitle: Stanley, Thomas B., Speech to the 1956 Constitutional Convention, 5 March 1956

scopecontent.p: Recording of Governor Thomas B. Stanley's opening speech to the 1956 Constitutional Convention. He expects the convention to play a major role in preventing forced integration and outlines the proposed revision to the Constitution whereas public funds can be used to support private schools.

did.unittitle: Stanley, Thomas B., State of the Commonwealth Address, 11 January 1956

scopecontent.p: State of the Commonwealth address, 11 January 1956, by Governor Thomas B. Stanley before the Virginia General Assembly. Topics covered include the 1954 United States Supreme Court decision on school desegregation and Virginia's response, Virginia's economy, employment levels, per capita income, coal production in southwest Virginia, labor/management relations, farm prices and the state's agricultural outlook, port trade and development, tourism, state government efficiency, the Governor's budget recommendations, and Virginia's tax structure and collections.

did.unittitle: State Highways' 50th Anniversary, 22 June 1956

scopecontent.p: Recording of the celebration of Virginia's primary highway system. Includes speeches from Governor Thomas B. Stanley and Senator Harry F. Byrd, Sr. Stanley discusses Byrd's role in the building of the road system and calls the fact that Virginia owes no money on the road system a tribute to Byrd's fight against the road bond issue in 1923. Byrd reminiscences about his involvement in the road business and describes the history and methods of road building in Virginia. He criticizes the increased centralization of power in the federal government and the growing national debt.

did.unittitle: Statements on the National Council of Churches in Christ, 11 December 1950

scopecontent.p: Statements, 11 December 1950, concerning a meeting of the National Council of Churches in Christ held in Cleveland, Ohio. Bishop Frederick D. Goodwin, Dr. John Marcus Ellison, and Dr. Hunter B. Blakely discuss their attendance at the meeting, and mention the setting and pageantry as they give an account and description of the gathering. The three also talk about the organization's purpose, and the cooperation between the regional and national group.

did.unittitle: Stephens Concession, 20 July 1961

scopecontent.p: A. E. S. Stephens concedes the Democratic nomination for Governor to Albertis S. Harrison. This recording runs from 4:50 to 5:13 and is on the same track as the statement and interview of Albertis S. Harrison.

did.unittitle: Stettinius, Edward R., 12 February 1947

scopecontent.p: A recording of a luncheon meeting for United Service to China volunteers held in the Washington Room of the John Marshall Hotel, Richmond, Virginia, on February 12, 1947. The meeting marks the kick-off of the Virginia drive to raise funds for the organization, which supports the educational, medical, agricultural and economic development of China and its people. Chairman for the Virginia campaign for United Service to China, Robert M. Hazelwood, presides over the luncheon. Dr. George Modlin, president of the University of Richmond, introduces the speaker, Edward R. Stettinius, who says that a "strong, free and friendly Chinais indispensable to our own security and prosperity" and refers to Secretary of State George C. Marshall's belief that giving money to China will help the world move toward lasting peace.

did.unittitle: Stevenson, Adlai E., Commencement Speech, Hampden-Sydney College, 2 July 1952

scopecontent.p: Stevenson returns as a commencement speaker to the college at which his great-grandfather, Lewis Warner Green, served as president from 1849 to 1856. He speaks about the issues facing the world today.

did.unittitle: Sunshine Sue, 14-15 May 1953

scopecontent.p: Track 1 contains: (0:12) "Blackberry Winter"; (3:45) "Love Me Now"; (6:18) "Search Me Lord". Track 2 contains: (0:08) "Where We'll Never Grow Old"; (2:35) "Hey Good Lookin'"; (5:28) "I Can't Help It If I'm Still in Love With You". Track 3 contains: (0:06) "Over the Valley"; (3:19) "I'm a Lovin' You". Track 4 contains: (0:07) "He Led the Way"; (2:26) "I'm Goin' There."

did.unittitle: Sunshine Sue, WRVA's 29th Anniversary, ca. 2 November 1954

scopecontent.p: Recording of an informal gathering with Virginia's first lady of song, Sunshine Sue (Mary Higdon Workman), including a special guest, a little music, and other odds and ends. This show includes the mystery personality contest, a reading of "What is a boy?," an interview with Dr. Vytautas J. Bieliauskas, Director of the School of Clinical and Applied Psychology at Richmond Professional Institute, about teenagers, Eddie Arnold singing "There's Been a Change in Me," and an interview with C. T. Lucy, General Manager of WRVA. The show was recorded on the occasion of WRVA's 29th Anniversary.

did.unittitle: Survivor's Story, 2 November 1950

scopecontent.p: Recording of another program in a series of programs celebrating WRVA's 25th anniversary. Contains a reenactment of part of WRVA's inaugural broadcast of 2 November 1925, Walter Bishop describing the inaugural broadcast and its participants, and interviews with participants of WRVA's inaugural broadcast, including Mrs. Henry P. Garber, Joe Maust, Bob Beadles, and Bertha Hewlett. Also includes Mrs. Henry P. Garber singing one of the same songs she sung on the inaugural broadcast, Joe Maust singing "My Wild Irish Rose," and the singing of "Carry Me Back to Ol' Virginny." The CD consists of three tracks, each containing the program "Survivor's Story." Track 1 is blank between the introduction of Mrs. Henry P. Garber and the end of the interview with Bertha Hewlett. Track 2 contains a complete recording of Survivor's Story. Track 3 is a shortened version of Track 2.

did.unittitle: Tape Morgue, 27 December 1978-31 December 1979
did.physdesc: 51 compact discs. Duration: 48 hr., 25 min., 28 sec.

scopecontent.p: These recordings consist of short takes of interviews, speeches or news reports used by WRVA when editing together programs and stories for broadcast. Topics usually focused on news stories from the Richmond-metro area, as well as from across the state.

did.unittitle: Teen Pregnancy: Ten-Part Documentary, October 1981

scopecontent.p: Ten-part documentary on teen pregnancy in the Richmond area, broadcast in October 1981. Includes comments by teenagers, parents, and health professionals. Statistics on numbers of sexually active teens are given, as well as the reasons and solutions to the growing problem. There are also figures provided on the level of contraception use and numbers of abortions in the Richmond area. Peer pressure, myths, and sex education programs are discussed, and options for pregnant teens, such as adoption, are covered. There is also a segment on pre-natal care and other referral services. Parents' skills in dealing with the issue and communicating with their teenager are also explored.

did.unittitle: Teen Suicide: WRVA documentary, November 1985

scopecontent.p: This documentary is a 10-part series focusing on teen suicide in Virginia, including interviews with teenagers who have attempted suicide, information on telephone hotlines, and interviews with medical personnel and counselors. Produced and reported by Renee Ridley.

did.unittitle: Testimonial Dinner for C. T. Lucy at the Commonwealth Club, 2 October 1961

scopecontent.p: Recording of the dinner organized by the Virginia Association of Broadcasters held in honor of C. T. Lucy on the occasion of his retirement from WRVA and Larus and Brother Company. The toastmaster was Verbon Kemp, executive director of the Virginia State Chamber of Commerce. Includes speeches by William T. Reed, Jr., president of Larus and Brother Company, C. T. Lucy, and Walter R. Bishop, WRVA public relations director. Kemp identifies some of the luminaries attending the dinner and introduces William T. Reed, Jr. Presenting him a silver tray for his many years of service, Reed praises Lucy's management of WRVA and helping make the station one of the best in Virginia. Lucy thanks the people who brought him to Richmond to work at Larus and Brother Company and started him in the radio business. After Lucy's speech, a spokesman for the Virginia Association of Broadcasters reads telegrams and resolutions from people unable to attend the dinner and presents Lucy with a television. Bishop presents Lucy with a heifer for his farm on behalf of WRVA. The Reverend Boyd R. Hawarth delivers the benediction.

did.unittitle: Thanksgiving Goodwill Mission by State Senator John Wicker, 19 November 1961

scopecontent.p: Coverage, 19 November 1961, of the Thanksgiving goodwill mission by former state Senator John J. Wicker (1893-1985) to Boston, on behalf of Governor J. Lindsay Almond, to visit Governor of Massachusetts John A. Volpe (1908-1994) and invite him to visit Virginia and attend a Thanksgiving celebration. Wicker discusses the "controversy" concerning where the first Thanksgiving was really celebrated, and offers proof that it was in Virginia. There is also a response to Wicker's assertions by Volpe. Also included is the musical piece "We Gather Together." Wicker is also interviewed prior to his trip, and discusses what he will be wearing.

did.unittitle: Thomas Jefferson's 250th Birthday Celebration at the Jefferson Hotel, 13 April 1993

scopecontent.p: Thomas Jefferson's 250th birthday celebration, held on 13 April 1993, at the Jefferson Hotel in downtown Richmond. Alden Aaroe and Tim Timberlake are the hosts of the live show, which features interview with special guests about various aspects of Jefferson's life and times, as well as various contests and drawings. The show also features the usual news, weather, and traffic reports, and commercial spots. Among the guests are the Jefferson Hotel's historian, as well as Ted Thompson, co-owner of Tuckahoe Plantation, Dr. Charles Brownell of Virginia Commonwealth University, University of Virginia doctoral student Robert Hopkins, and Travis McDonald of Poplar Forest.

did.unittitle: Today's Virginian, 25 October 1950

scopecontent.p: Recording of two programs of Today's Virginian. Hosted by Bill Willis. The first program contains an interview with Frederic Heutte (1899-1979), superintendent of parks and forestry for Norfolk, Virginia, including biographical information and the history of the Norfolk Azalea Gardens (now Norfolk Botanical Gardens). The second program, beginning at 4:30, contains an interview with the Reverend G. I. McAllen, also know as Daddy Mac. Reverend McAllen was a Methodist minister who spent his life devoted to the dependent children of Virginia. WRVA's listeners nominated these men in celebration of WRVA's 25th anniversary. Neither interview is complete. Recording ends with an unidentified singer singing "Some Enchanted Evening."

did.unittitle: Today's Virginian: Interview with Holland R. Wilkinson, 2 November 1950

scopecontent.p: Scott Jarrett of WRVA interviews Holland R. Wilkinson (1893-1954), host of WRVA's The Sunshine Hour, nominated by WRVA's listeners in celebration of the station's 25th anniversary. Wilkinson discusses his life, including his first appearance on WRVA on Christmas Eve 1925, how he became an evangelist, and his work with children amputees.

did.unittitle: Top 40 on 1140 with Lyle Bradley, 25 May 1957

scopecontent.p: Includes most popular musical selections based on Billboard and Variety magazines, and listeners' requests to WRVA. Among the songs played are "Butterfly" by Andy Williams, "Chantez Chantez" by Dinah Shore, "Love Letters in the Sand" by Pat Boone, "Empty Arms" by Teresa Brewer, and "Ninety Nine Ways" by Tab Hunter. Bradley also reads commercial spots for Shield-All window awnings and Dairy Queen. There is also a commercial for Richbrau Beer.

did.unittitle: Tornado Reports, 14-16 June 1951
did.physdesc: 3 compact discs. Duration: 1 hr., 19 min., 54 sec.

scopecontent.p: These recordings consist of news reports covering Richmond's first-ever recorded tornado that cut a swath through the city on 14 June 1951. The storm traveled a winding path northeastward across the James River, through the downtown area, hitting Byrd Park, Monroe Park, several tobacco warehouses and up through the Shockoe Valley. Details are provided on the city clean-up process, casualty reports and the civil defense response of the Richmond police, as well as interviews with local citizens. George Passage and Alden Aaroe are featured reporters.

did.unittitle: Traffic Safety, 6 September 1947

scopecontent.p: Concerns Virginia's efforts to improve traffic safety and the role of WRVA in encouraging traffic safety. Includes excerpts from a speech of Governor William M. Tuck concerning highway and traffic safety, a statement from E. H. Williams, Jr., executive director of the Governor's Highway Safety Committee, an interview with Colonel C. W. Woodson, superintendent of the Virginia State Police, and information on the Governor's Highway Safety Committee, the establishment of local safety committees, and traffic safety in Norfolk and Richmond. Also includes a meeting between WRVA staff and the following nine individuals: Colonel C. W. Woodson; G. Watson James, special executive assistant, Division of Motor Vehicles; Dr. Harold K. Jack, Department of Health; Burton Marye, Highway Department; Giles Robertson, executive secretary, Virginia Association of Insurance Agencies; Charles Ray, chief safety and engineering section, Market Service; Captain W. L. Grove(?), safety engineer, State Police; Ralph Saunders, Virginia Highway Users Association; and Dr. G. B. Hancock, Virginia Union University. The meeting includes the discussion of ideas to improve the promotion of traffic safety broadcasting on WRVA. The user should listen to the tracks in this order: track 1, track 3 (mislabeled part 4), and track 2.

did.unittitle: Tribute to Alden Aaroe: WRVA News Documentary, 1993

scopecontent.p: This program was broadcast as a tribute to Alden Aaroe, who died on 7 July 1993. Consists of biographical information and sound clips of Alden Aaroe from his forty-seven years of broadcasting over WRVA. Produced and narrated by John Harding, WRVA news director. A verbatim transcript of John Harding's narrative and references to the sound clips is located in Box 17, Folder Aaroe, Alden - "A Tribute to Alden Aaroe," WRVA Radio News Documentary, 1993.

did.unittitle: Tribute to Ella Funk Myers, 25 May 1938

scopecontent.p: Broadcast of the tribute to Ella Funk Myers sponsored by the Richmond Federation of Garden Clubs and aired over WRVA Radio. Includes tributes from fellow garden club members, the Richmond Times-Dispatch, and WRVA Radio, containing information regarding her service with Richmond Times-Dispatch and WRVA, her love of gardening, and her efforts to promote gardening.

did.unittitle: Tribute to Howard Bloom, 28 May 1974
did.physdesc: 2 compact discs. Duration: 1 hr., 40 min., 15 sec.

scopecontent.p: Recording of the tribute to Howard Bloom, including clips of comments and readings from his memorial service, comments by dignitaries, as well as employees of WRVA, on Bloom's work as a traffic reporter for the station, instrumental music and clips of Bloom's reporting, and a segment of "Open for Opinion," hosted by Larry Dodd, including listeners' calls to the station with their reminiscences of Bloom. Howard Bloom (1943-1974), a traffic reporter for WRVA, died after his helicopter lost its tail rotor and crashed into a building in downtown Richmond.

did.unittitle: Tribute to Publisher William Younger Morgan, 21 December 1946

scopecontent.p: 1 compact disc. This recording consists of a brief tribute to William Younger Morgan, owner, publisher and editor of the Northern Neck News from Warsaw, Virginia, in commemoration of his 67th anniversary with the newspaper.

did.unittitle: Truman, Harry S., Speech at Monticello, 4 July 1947

scopecontent.p: Speech, 4 July 1947, by President Harry S. Truman at Monticello, the home of Thomas Jefferson. Speaking before members of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation, Truman discusses Thomas Jefferson and the Declaration of Independence and the correlation between the establishment of the United Nations and the Declaration of Independence. He calls the United Nations Charter a declaration of interdependence. He outlines ways to achieve peace between nations in the context of Jefferson's principles and writings and the efforts of the United States in achieving peace throughout the world. The Charlottesville Municipal Band performs the national anthem. Recorded and broadcast by the Columbia Broadcasting Service (CBS).

did.unittitle: Tuck, William M., Campaign Speech, ca. 1945

scopecontent.p: Campaign speech, ca. 1945, of Lieutenant Governor William M. Tuck while campaigning for the governorship. Tuck praises Virginia's accomplishments and outlines his plans for education, health, agriculture, and the physically and mentally disabled. He promises to maintain the principles of good government and continued freedom from debt. He emphasizes his political experience and believes the election of a Republican as governor would be disastrous considering the overwhelming majority of Democrats in the legislature. Broadcast paid for by the Democratic State Committee.

did.unittitle: Tuck, William M., Farewell Address, 11 January 1950

scopecontent.p: This broadcast begins with commentary from Ray Kennedy and George Passage on the upcoming General Assembly session and the administration of William M. Tuck. Beginning on the second track of the first CD, Tuck delivers his farewell address, reviewing the accomplishments of his administration and criticizing the growing centralization of the federal government. After the speech, Walter R. Bishop, WRVA Public Relations Director, offers his thoughts on Tuck's address.

did.unittitle: Tuck, William M., Governor Tuck, 6 January 1947

scopecontent.p: Titled Governor Tuck, this is a recording of Tuck's address before a joint session of the General Assembly, which convened to consider increasing "salaries of public school teachers, labor legislation and other matters which may appear urgent." The speech takes place in the Hall of the House of Delegates in the Virginia State Capitol, in a gallery "unusually well-filled" with proponents and opponents of both the labor issues and public educators' salaries. Tuck discusses the Denny Commission of 1944-1945 created with the goal of analyzing and improving the school system and says that despite gains, the Virginia public school system is in grave condition due to the scarcity of qualified teachers. On labor, Tuck discusses a bill he introduced supporting the right to work regardless of affiliation or non-affiliation with a labor organization.

did.unittitle: Tuck, William M., Governor Tuck Speech, 7 December 1947

scopecontent.p: This is a recording of the keynote speech by Governor Tuck on the sixth anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. Tuck is introduced by Richmond mayor, Horace Edwards. Tuck expounds upon Virginia's and Virginians' patriotic roles in United States history and discusses the importance of Virginia's "Declaration of Rights." He warns of subversive influences at home and the expansion of the federal government. Following Tuck's speech, attendees recite the "Freedom Pledge," which is followed by Langley Field's 564th Air Force Band's rendition of the "Star Spangled Banner" and other patriotic songs.

did.unittitle: Tuck, William M., Interview, 29 November 1946

scopecontent.p: Governor Tuck is interviewed regarding his views on the current labor problem, meaning specifically a coal strike led by the United Mine Workers. According to Tuck, the coal strike, in which miners walked off the job without any regard for the public interest or public safety, was a very unpatriotic action. He calls for the repeal of the Wagner Labor Act, allowing states, not the federal government, to regulate labor. He calls the strike an insurrection, "a challenge by highly organized, blindly following minorities against law and public morality." He blames labor unrest on "the gang of dangerous and desperate despots" and politicians more interested "in enjoying the fruits of their office than they are in the public welfare." Interviewer also references Tuck's March 1946 threat to draft electric and power company workers into the Virginia Militia to prevent them from striking and asks him his opinion on John L. Lewis, the president of the United Mine Workers. Tuck also discusses the State Corporation Commission's charge against Lewis and the United Mine Workers for selling union memberships in Virginia, a suit first brought by the Richmond Better Business Bureau.

did.unittitle: Tuck, William M., Speech, 22 October 1952
