scopecontent.p: Recording of a paid advertisement of William M. Tuck speaking from WBTM studios in Danville, Virginia. Tuck announces that he cannot support the Stevenson-Sparkman ticket because of Stevenson's support of Truman's program. He criticizes excessive spending, Trumanism, the Fair Employment Practices Commission (FEPC), and labor unions. He believes that passage of the bill creating the FEPC would make life in the South unbearable. Tuck believes that Eisenhower adheres more strictly to the principles of the Democratic Party than Stevenson.

did.unittitle: Tuck, William M., Virginia Association of Broadcasters Award, 10 January 1950

scopecontent.p: Recording of a ceremony and speech in which Governor William Tuck is presented the Virginia Association of Broadcasters (VAB) Award by VAB President, Phillip Allen of Lynchburg, for his wise and intelligent use of radio during his term as governor in order to reach the people of Virginia directly.

did.unittitle: The Tunnel, 2 October 1968

scopecontent.p: Recording of a documentary on the 1925 Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad tunnel collapse in the Church Hill district of Richmond, Virginia, narrated by Derwood Felton. The history of the accident is documented, and includes information on the tunnel's construction, and the fear of its collapse in the 1870's. Includes comments by local historians and people who witnessed the aftermath of the accident, as well as information on the rescue efforts to save any survivors. The end of the recording features a commercial spot for the program.

did.unittitle: United Press International Award Competition Entry for 1960

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1960 United Press International award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories include the announcement of the state budget surplus by Governor J. Lindsay Almond and State Senator Harry F. Byrd, Jr.'s reaction, as well as Richmond/Henrico County merger/annexation and the naming of the Richmond's negotiating team, a federal suit filed by the Petersburg Improvement Association against segregated lunch counter seating, and the legal ruling on the constitutionality of Virginia's "Sunday Closing" law. There is also a commercial spot for Jones Motorcar Company in Richmond.

did.unittitle: University of Virginia Inauguration of Edgar Shannon, 6 October 1959
did.physdesc: 2 compact discs. Duration: 1 hr., 23 min., 20 sec.

scopecontent.p: Recording of the ceremony surrounding the inauguration of Edgar Shannon as president of the University of Virginia. Includes speeches by Governor J. Lindsay Almond, Jr., Geoffrey R. G. Mure, warden of Merton College, Oxford University, and Edgar Shannon. Mure recounts Shannon's years as a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford University. Shannon speaks on the purpose of higher learning and outlines his vision for the university.

did.unittitle: U.S.S. Forrestal, Christening of, Newport News, 11 December 1954

scopecontent.p: Christening ceremony, 11 December 1954, for the aircraft carrier U.S.S. Forrestal (CVA-59), at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company in Newport News, Virginia. Includes the playing of the National Anthem, and comments by William E. Blewett, company president, and Admiral Robert B. Carney, Chief of Naval Operations, as well as Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson, and Secretary of the Navy Charles S. Thomas. There is also an invocation, and coverage of the actual christening by Mrs. James V. Forrestal.

did.unittitle: U.S.S. Forrestal, Keel-Laying Ceremonies at Newport News, 14 July 1952

scopecontent.p: Coverage of the keel-laying ceremonies for the U.S.S. Forrestal (CVA-59), at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, on 14 July 1952. Includes the playing of the National Anthem, and comments by William E. Blewett, company president, Secretary of the Navy Dan A. Kimball, and Deputy Secretary of Defense William C. Foster.

did.unittitle: Variety Plaque Awards, 17 February 1943

scopecontent.p: A recording of the special program recognizing WRVA for its contributions "to let every military man it could reach be assured that we Americans are 100% behind him." WRVA received the special award, presented by Variety Magazine, for its "distinctive merit in a field of war endeavor, for contributions to military-civilian understanding." The program provides an overview of the WRVA broadcast programs from various camps around the state, with samples from several programs Also included are speeches, such as one by Major General James E. Edmonds, Commanding General of Camp Lee; Virginia Governor Colgate W. Darden, Jr.; Barron Howard, Business Manager of WRVA; Irving Abeloff, WRVA Program Service Manager; and C.T. Lucy, WRVA General Manager.

did.unittitle: Vintage Clip Collection for WRVA's 65th Birthday Celebrations, 1990

scopecontent.p: Collection of vintage clips from WRVA for use in its numerous 65th anniversary celebrations in 1990. Includes statements by C. T. Lucy, William T. Reed, Jr., as well as Dick Gillis announcing an upcoming election, Jack Clements and Harry Monroe announcing a portion of the 1956 edition of "This is Virginia," and a portion of the "Old Dominion Barn Dance." There are also commercial spots, and a clip of Art Linkletter's "Pillsbury House Party," Reverend W. Taliaferro Thompson giving the invocation on the station's 20th anniversary show, clips from "Music for the Day," and "Radio Scholarship Quiz," an interview with Bertha Hewlett, portions of Alden Aaroe speaking, and the agricultural report.

did.unittitle: Virginia 1956, 31 December 1956

scopecontent.p: "This is Virginia, the 1956 edition". Major news stories of 1956 in Virginia hosted by Jack Clements and Harry Monroe. The segregation issue is the overriding theme of the year. Includes rundown of the segregation related events throughout 1956, including the passage of the Interposition resolution in the General Assembly, the closing of Seashore State Park, the special session of the General Assembly, the Gray Plan, the Stanley Plan, and Pupil assignment. Other major news stories include the school bond issue, the death of Alben Barkely at the Washington and Lee University Mock Political Convention, the 1956 Democratic National Convention in Chicago, the Republican National Convention, the Richmond city jail, and the Richmond-Petersburg Turnpike.

did.unittitle: Virginia 1960 News Highlights, 31 December 1960

scopecontent.p: Harry Monroe and Lon Backman, WRVA news broadcasters, look back at the major news events in Virginia of 1960, including a Capitol Airlines plane crash, integration of Richmond's schools, the sales tax battle in the General Assembly, the arrest of Harry L. Donovan and the scandal of Richmond police officers being on his payroll, sit-ins across Virginia to protest segregation, Henrico County floods, the merger of Henrico County and Richmond, downtown redevelopment, Richmond city elections, an interview with Oliver Powers on the capture of his son, U-2 pilot Francis Gary Powers, the national Democratic and Republican conventions, and the beginning of construction on the Chesapeake Bay-Bridge Tunnel.

did.unittitle: Virginia 1961

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Harry Monroe and Lon Backman, this recording features news highlights of 1961 and clips from previous shows. The date of broadcast is unknown. News stories covered include the Richmond police bureau investigation, Imperial Airlines crash, Hurricane Esther, Virginia elections, Richmond and Henrico County consolidation, demolition of the John Marshall High School, Sheltering Arms hospital donation drive, Civil War centennial observances, Richmond City Council proceedings, and the dedication of the new WRVA transmitter facilities.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entry for 1978

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1978 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories include the U.S. Senate race in Virginia and the death of Republican candidate Richard D. Obenshain (1936-1978), and the subsequent nomination of John W. Warner and his victory. There is also a segment on the Richmond City Council, and the disappearance of Raymond D. Royall, a Council member, and his reappearance in St. Louis, as well as the criminal background of William I. Golding, another Council member. Also covered is the firing of Richmond City Manager William J. Leidinger by the Council. Other stories include the Richmond convention center project, stadium expansion plans, and Richmond police news.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entry for 1979

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1979 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories include the snow emergency and winter storm that affected Virginia, the energy crisis, accident at the North Anna nuclear power plant and the vandalism and bomb scare at the nuclear facility in Surry, the strike at Newport News Shipbuilding, controversy surrounding Dana B. Hamel as chancellor of the Virginia Community College System, the purchasing and supply scandal in state government, Richmond City Council news, race relations in Richmond, General Assembly elections, Tropical Storm David, and various crime stories and accidents in Richmond, including a hostage situation at Southern Bank and Trust, traffic accident on Interstate 64, and fire in the Shockoe Slip district.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entry for 1980

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1980 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories include the blizzard affecting Virginia and the summer drought conditions, General Assembly news and Governor John Dalton's legislative agenda, equal rights amendment supporters, the Richmond tax referendum, Chesterfield County school bond referendum, national political conventions and the election of Ronald Reagan, Virginia congressional elections, Henrico County jail escape, a story on the history of mass sterilization at a mental institution in Lynchburg, the nomination of James E. Sheffield as federal judge, and various accidents and investigatory segments reported on by WRVA, including a chemical leak, school bus accident, pollution of the Piney River, substance abuse in Chesterfield County schools, and state investments of tax monies.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entry for 1981

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1981 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories include the repeal of the state sales tax on food and the budget surplus, redistricting, the U.S. Senate campaigns of Charles Robb and Marshall Coleman, the state budget crisis and budget cuts in Richmond and Chesterfield County, strikes by federal air traffic controllers and state coal miners, the death of Colgate Darden, Harry F. Byrd Jr.'s decision not to seek reelection, the merging of Miller and Rhoads with a New York company, the crash of a military jet aboard the U.S.S. Nimitz, and the 200th anniversary of the Battle of Yorktown. There also spots on WRVA's investigative reports on teen pregnancy, retreats by state employees, the gubernatorial race, and Richmond's homeless population.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entry for 1982

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1981 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories include the inauguration of Governor Charles S. Robb and his first State of the Commonwealth Address, the rise in the gas tax to fund road construction, the major winter storm that affected the state, Richmond City Council elections, a train derailment in Richmond, the execution of death row inmate Frank Coppola, the United States Senate race in Virginia and candidates Owen Pickett, L. Douglas Wilder, Paul Trible, and Richard Davis, and the release of the toxic chemical pentaborane in Hanover County. There are also spots for various investigative reports by WRVA including drug smuggling at a Richmond terminal port and a series on birth defects.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entry for 1984

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1984 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories include the snowstorm that affected the state, Governor Charles S. Robb's budget proposals and the raising of the legal drinking age, a large fire at a Richmond packaging plant, the severe drought in the state, anniversary of Martin Luther King, Jr.'s "I Have aDream" speech, and Richmond's city budget. There are also segments on investigative reports done by WRVA, including a story on the Virginia State Game Commission, an audit of Richmond's drug rehabilitation program, and child abuse.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Best News Operation Entry for 1984

scopecontent.p: This recording contains sound clips of WRVA news coverage of the top stories in Virginia of 1984 including: the escape and recapture of six death row inmates from Mecklenburg Correctional Center in Boydton, Virginia; the Virginia General Assembly session; the proposal to extend Route 288; the election of Roy West to the Richmond City Council; the United States Senate election between Democrat Edythe Harrison and Republican John Warner; the presidential election between Ronald Reagan and Walter Mondale; the opening of Richmond's Sixth Marketplace; the nomination of J. Harvie Wilkinson, III, to the Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals; and the execution of Linwood Briley. Also mentions the WRVA News Documentaries focusing on spousal abuse, daycare centers, and Kepone.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Best News Operation Entry for 1985

scopecontent.p: This recording contains sound clips of WRVA news coverage of the top stories of 1985 including: the James River Flood in November; the fire at the Southern Railway Warehouse at 13th and Main Streets in Richmond; the Virginia General Assembly; the inmate riot at the Richmond State Penitentiary over the scheduled execution of James Briley; the execution of James Briley; the dedication of Richmond's 6th Street Festival Marketplace; the march against crime and the soaring murder rate in Richmond; the march against apartheid in Washington, D. C.; the election of Gerald Baliles as governor, Doug Wilder as lieutenant governor, and Mary Sue Terry as attorney-general; Chesterfield County's bond referendum proposal; Hurricane Gloria; and the fire at a Southern States Feed Company warehouse at 1st and Maury Streets in Richmond. Also mentions the WRVA News Documentaries focusing on AIDS, teen suicide, and Richmond's political, social, and economic growing pains. Narrated by Tim Timberlake.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entry for 1986

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1986 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories include the inauguration of Gerald L. Baliles and Charles Robb's last State of the Commonwealth address, General Assembly debate on the state lottery proposal and conflict of interest legislation, the Challenger explosion, Richmond City Council elections, violent crime in Richmond, gas explosion in the Manchester area, the conviction of Richmond stockbroker Clyde Pitchford, state highway improvements and tax increases, the execution of Michael Marnell Smith, and Alden Aaroe's 40th anniversary with WRVA. There are also segments on investigative reports done by the station, including Richmond's "slum lords," and group homes for the mentally retarded.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entry for 1987

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1987 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories include debate in the Virginia General Assembly on the lottery referendum bill and approval of the referendum by voters, snowstorms and traffic problems in Richmond, various fires, a civil rights march in Colonial Heights led by Reverend Curtis W. Harris, flooding of the James River, shootings in Richmond and Petersburg, a leak at the North Anna nuclear power plant, local elections for the General Assembly, coverage of the Richmond Newspapers marathon, and clips on investigative series, including care of elderly parents, aging nuclear power facilities, and crime.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entry for 1988

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1988 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories include snowstorms and travel problems in Richmond, Governor Gerald L. Baliles' State of the Commonwealth Address, a WRVA editorial on sex education legislation, Richmond City Council elections, the proposal on the location of Route 288 in western Henrico County, opening of the Powhite Parkway road extension, a hostage situation at an armed forces recruiting station, chemical spill on Interstate 95, a demonstration by inmates at a state prison, various local, state, and national elections, spots for investigative series on child leukemia and eating disorders, various WRVA editorial clips, and coverage of the Richmond Newspapers marathon.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entry for 1989

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1988 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories include the Virginia gubernatorial race between L. Douglas Wilder and J. Marshall Coleman and the resulting recount, a snowstorm that hit Richmond, gun control legislation in the General Assembly, pollution released into the Shenandoah River at Front Royal by Avtex Fibers, Inc., a strike by the United Mine Workers and their rally at the State Capitol, various train, airplane and vehicle accidents in the Richmond area, a fire at a Richmond paper plant, riots in Virginia Beach, a spot for WRVA's series on psychiatric hospitals for children, an editorial by the station on the admission of women at the Virginia Military Institute, and various sports stories, including coverage of the Richmond Newspapers marathon.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entry for 1990

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1990 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories include the inauguration of Governor L. Douglas Wilder, the state's budget shortfall, Richmond City Council elections, the historic area designation for the Church Hill district of Richmond, rapid growth and development in Chesterfield County, various crime stories and accidents in Richmond, a spot for WRVA's series on domestic violence, editorial clips by the station, and coverage of the Richmond Newspapers marathon.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Award Competition Entries, 1991
did.physdesc: 1 compact disc. Duration: 1 hr., 18 min., 46 sec.

scopecontent.p: Various entries by WRVA in the 1991 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. WRVA-596 includes a story entitled "Chuck Robb's Year of Discontent," which chronicles the drug use and adultery charges against U.S. Senator Charles S. Robb while he was Governor of Virginia. There are also clips concerning the controversy between him and L. Douglas Wilder, and the alleged taping of telephone conversations of Wilder by Robb, and subsequent investigations. There are interviews with various individuals concerning Robb's behavior, including author Billy A. Franklin and Larry Sabato. The second segment concerns WRVA's sports coverage, including clips of call-in programs, commentaries, and coverage of NASCAR races, the Tour du Pont bicycle race, Richmond Newspapers marathon, and the Virginia state motorcycle championship. The final segment includes stories on the station's Gulf War coverage, General Assembly debate on the state budget and redistricting, weather and storm coverage, a pardon by Governor Wilder, Wilder's presidential bid, anti-abortion demonstrations, local elections for county supervisors, and an investigation of Richmond's ambulance service business. WRVA-597 contains a segment on the abduction and murder of 10-year-old Charity Powers in Chesterfield County on 6 October 1990, including clips on her initial disappearance and the search for her body, the discovery of her remains, the arrest of Everett Lee Mueller, coverage of the Powers funeral, and Mueller's trial, guilty verdict, and his death sentence. Mueller was executed on 16 September 1991. There is also a segment on a hostage situation that occurred in Amelia County, when a 16-year-old youth from Cumberland County held numerous people captive in a store. There are clips covering negotiations between the suspect and police, comments by released hostages, and reports on who the suspect is and his motive.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entry for 1991

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1991 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories include the station's Gulf War coverage, General Assembly debate on the state budget and redistricting, the abduction and murder of 10-year-old Charity Powers in Chesterfield County, drug use and adultery charges against U.S. Senator Charles S. Robb while he was Governor of Virginia, local elections for county supervisors, closing of the Thalhimer's department store in Richmond, a hostage situation that occurred in Amelia County, storm coverage, spots for WRVA's investigative reports on the shortage of organ donors, as well as Richmond's ambulance service business, and coverage of numerous sports stories, including the Richmond Newspapers marathon. Portions of this recording are also on WRVA - 596-597.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entries for 1992
did.physdesc: 3 compact discs. Duration: 2 hrs., 5 min., 5 sec.

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entries in various categories in the 1992 Virginia Association of Broadcasters awards competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories included on WRVA - 482 include the rising crime rate in Richmond and the rally that was held at the State Capitol, pleas from the community, gun control legislation and opposition by the National Rifle Association and General Assembly, gun trafficking, anti-drug and anti-crime programs, and station editorials. This disc also contains various sports stories covered by WRVA, such as the NASCAR races in Richmond, Tour du Pont bicycle race, Lanny Watkins golf tournament, Richmond Times-Dispatch newspaper marathon, Professional Putters' Association, international semi-professional football, and call-in shows and radio commentaries. The end of the recording features miscellaneous local, state, national, and world news stories. WRVA - 483 contains segments on the proposed move of the Washington Redskins football team to Alexandria, and includes stories on Governor L. Douglas Wilder's meetings with Jack Kent Cooke and the collapse of negotiations, opposition by Alexandria residents, information on the Potomac Yard site, state subsidies, site clean-up, a proposal to bring the team to Richmond, and station editorials. Also included on this disc are segments on the Chesterfield County shrink-swell soil controversy, and the resulting commission set up to investigate allegations by various homeowners concerning damage to their homes, inspection violations, damage and repair costs, responsible parties, the prosecution of developers, a federal grand jury investigation, extent of the problem, public hearings, and recommendations, as well as editorials by WRVA. WRVA - 483 contains various news segments, including stories on Richmond police confrontations in Mosby Court, Amtrak train derailment, Republican convention highlights, the presidential campaign of Ross Perot, the presidential debate at the University of Richmond, Richmond Newspapers marathon, election results, General Assembly news, plane crash in Henrico County, and James River flooding in downtown Richmond.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entry for 1992

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1992 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories include the presidential election and Governor L. Douglas Wilder withdrawing from the race, the campaign of H. Ross Perot, and the debate at the University of Richmond, Virginia congressional elections, the bond referendum approved by the General Assembly, Richmond City Council elections, the execution of Roger Keith Coleman, the shrink swell controversy in Chesterfield County, a WRVA editorial on the Americans with Disabilities Act, the possible relocation of the Washington Redskins to Alexandria, Amtrak train derailment in Newport News and other miscellaneous accident stories, a spot for WRVA's series on elderly drivers, editorial on the admission of women to the Virginia Military Institute, and coverage of the Richmond Newspapers marathon. Portions of this recording are also on WRVA - 481-483.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entry for 1993

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1993 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. WRVA-484 includes stories on the funeral of Arthur Ashe, a snowstorm that hit Virginia, state Republican Party convention coverage, a semi-trailer accident on Interstate 95, and the temporary dismissal of Joe Morrissey as Richmond's Commonwealth Attorney. Most of the disc is devoted to coverage of a school bus accident in Chesterfield County, and a fire at the Shoe Tree business in downtown Richmond. WRVA-485 includes stories on a tornado in Colonial Heights, coverage of Hurricane Emily, the Virginia gubernatorial race, the threatened closing of Fort Lee, gun control legislation, and the trial of State Senator Bill Russell.

did.unittitle: Virginia Association of Broadcasters Awards Competition Entry for 1994

scopecontent.p: WRVA's entry in the 1994 Virginia Association of Broadcasters award competition. Features news highlights as reported by the station for the year. Stories include coverage of the state Republican convention, an automobile accident on Interstate 95 near Ashland, Virginia, explosion at Fort A.P. Hill, Richmond Newspapers marathon, U.S. Senate race between Charles Robb and Oliver North, execution of Christopher C. Goins and the crimes he committed, inauguration of Governor George Allen, local political races, and miscellaneous stories on area fires and crime. There are also spots for stories WRVA did on divorce and the Richmond flood wall.

did.unittitle: Virginia Constitutional Convention Proceedings, 5-7 March 1956
did.physdesc: 7 compacts discs. Duration: 5 hrs., 9 min., 35 sec.

scopecontent.p: Proceedings, 5-7 March 1956, of the state constitutional convention which met in Richmond, Virginia, including opening remarks by Governor Thomas B. Stanley.

did.unittitle: Virginia Council of Churches Roundtable, 25 January 1953

scopecontent.p: This is a recording of a presentation made in conjunction with the annual meeting of the Virginia Council of Churches Roundtable. Speakers provide a brief history of the Council, a discussion of the organization's work from 1952 and planned projects for 1953, the accomplishments of the organization and the promotion of the observances of the publication of the revised Standard Bible across the state, the training of all kinds of church workers in the communities, weekday religious education, and the group's Youth Council.

did.unittitle: Virginia Democratic Primary Election Coverage, 9 July 1957

scopecontent.p: Coverage of the 1957 Democratic primary elections in Virginia by WRVA radio, broadcast on 9 July 1957, and reported by Jack Clements and Chuck Sweeney. Includes updates from Richmond precincts for Governor and House of Delegates seat races, and statewide updates for Governor. There are also statements by Howard H. Carwile, J. Lindsay Almond, Josephine Almond, Fred G. Pollard, and FitzGerald (Jerry) Bemiss. Sweeney reports from Norfolk with results on that area's House of Delegates seats. There are also updates for the races in Alexandria, Pittsylvania County, Prince William County, Stafford County, Spotsylvania County/Fredericksburg, Charlottesville, Hanover County, and King William County.

did.unittitle: Virginia Electric and Power Company Celebration, September 1950

scopecontent.p: Recording of the celebration of the connection of electrical service to the 500,000th customer of the Virginia Electrical and Power Company (VEPCO). Includes recognition of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Murray of Halifax County, Virginia, the 500,000th customer, and presentation of an electric oven, refrigerator, and a radio to the Murrays, and speeches from Jack Holtzsclaw, VEPCO president, and former Governor William M. Tuck. Holtzclaw discusses the program of rural electrification after World War II. Tuck speaks on the benefits of electricity and the changes electricity has brought to rural living, and criticizes labor unions and their role in the interruption of public services in places other than Virginia. George Passage, WRVA News Editor, is master of ceremonies. Passage also interviews Mrs. Murray on the changes electricity will bring to her life.

did.unittitle: Virginia Electric and Power Company Public Service Announcements, 1940s

scopecontent.p: Public service announcements from the Virginia Electric and Power Company calling for consumers to conserve electricity to help the war effort. Includes duplicate recordings. Electrically transcribed by Ready Kilowatt. This recording is track 2 on WRVA - 11.

did.unittitle: Virginia Farm News, 3 December 1950

scopecontent.p: News of Virginia's farm scene. Includes market roundup, crop updates, livestock and poultry news, and information on soil testing, home pasteurization, 4-H, and the 100 bushel corn club certificate.

did.unittitle: Virginia Legislators' Interview, 10 January 1950

scopecontent.p: Interviews with legislators at the Hotel Richmond arriving in Richmond for the biennial session of the General Assembly. Hosted by Walter Bishop, WRVA director of public relations, and State Senator Charles W. Crowder of Richmond. Crowder outlines the major issues facing the General Assembly. The legislators discuss their length of service, the committees on which they serve, and the legislation with which they are most concerned. The legislators interviewed are Delegate L. Lake Tripplet of Fauquier County, Delegate Paul Crockett of Williamsburg, and James City, York, New Kent, and Charles City Counties, Delegate Joseph J. Williams, Jr. of Henrico County, Delegate George Damm of Arlington County, Delegate Charles M. Waldrop of Amelia and Nottoway Counties, and Senator Morton G. Goode of Petersburg and Dinwiddie County.

did.unittitle: Virginia Legislators' Interview, 12 January 1956

scopecontent.p: Interviews with legislators at the Hotel Richmond arriving in Richmond for the biennial session of the General Assembly. Hosted by Walter Bishop, WRVA director of public relations. The legislators discuss their length of service, the committees on which they serve, and the legislation with which they are most concerned. The legislators interviewed are: Delegate Joseph J. Williams, Jr., of Henrico County, Delegate J. Maynard Magruder of Arlington County, Delegate Kathryn H. Stone of Arlington County, Delegate Hunt M. Whitehead of Pittsylvania County, Delegate Vernon S. Shaffer of Shenandoah County, Delegate Russell M. Carneal of Williamsburg, and Delegate Lucas D. Phillips of Loudoun County.

did.unittitle: Virginia News 1958, 3 January 1959

scopecontent.p: Recording of "This Is Virginia", the 1958 edition, hosted by Harry Monroe, Frank Wilson, and Jack Clements. Contains a recap of the top news stories in Virginia in 1958, including the closing of schools in Charlottesville, Norfolk, and Warren County to prevent integration; the General Assembly's passage of the first billion dollar budget; Governor Almond's inauguration; Senator Byrd's announcement that he would not seek re-election; Virginia's reaction to Senator Byrd's announcement causing him to change his mind; the explosion at the Merchants Cold Storage building; the appointment of Bishop John J. Russell as Bishop of the Diocese of Virginia; the opening of the Richmond-Petersburg Turnpike; the opening of the Reynolds Metals office building; and downtown revitalization including the Federal office building project and the Richmond civic center. This program also includes a recap of disasters, crimes, weather news, business stories, and deaths of prominent Virginians occurring in Virginia in 1958, and information on the WRVA news boat and plane.

did.unittitle: Virginians Baseball Press Party: Announcement of WRVA Radio Contract to Broadcast Virginians in 1961 with Ballentine Beer as Sponsor, 22 November 1960

scopecontent.p: Recording of luncheon banquet, including statements and speeches announcing that the Richmond Virginians, a minor league baseball team affiliated with the New York Yankees, will broadcast its game on WRVA. This recording is incomplete.

did.unittitle: Virginia Pattern for Resistance, [1958 or 1959]

scopecontent.p: This is a recording of a program, hosted by Walter Cronkite, highlighting the "voices of Virginians speaking on one issue: the schools and who will attend them." The issue is school integration and Virginia's legislated agenda to prevent desegregation in the public schools, also known as Massive Resistance. The program is marked by sound bites from Governor Almond, as well as discussions of the Virginia General Assembly's passage of laws forcing the closure of schools forced to integrate and giving the governor the power either to reopen the schools on a segregated basis or deny state funding to those that do integrate. The program also includes quotes from officials and citizens on both sides of the issue. Specific situations in Norfolk, Arlington and Charlottesville are discussed in detail, with Cronkite's ultimately concludes that "Virginians are not of a single mind" on this issue.

did.unittitle: Virginia Republican Party Convention Coverage, 6 July 1957

scopecontent.p: Coverage, by Harry Monroe of WRVA, of the Virginia Republican Party convention, held in Roanoke on 6 July 1957. Monroe reports on the Nominating Committee going into executive session, and the controversy over the nomination for attorney general.

did.unittitle: Virginia Republican Party Convention Coverage, 6 July 1957

scopecontent.p: Coverage of the Virginia Republican Party convention, held in Roanoke on 6 July 1957, by Jack Clements, Walter Bishop, and Harry Monroe of WRVA. The recording begins with off-air remarks, then highlights of the convention are discussed, including the enthusiasm of the convention participants, the number of young people participating, and the call to get out the vote. The nominees for the top three state offices are given, and mention is made of the Nominating Committee going into executive session to discuss the controversy over the nomination for attorney general. The party platform is also covered.

did.unittitle: Virginia Sings: Farmville State Teachers College and Hampden-Sydney, 2 December 1946
did.physdesc: 2 compact discs. Duration: 1 hr., 2 min., 32 sec.

scopecontent.p: WRVA - 60 contains a choral performance by the Farmville State Teacher's College Glee Club with special guests, the Hampden-Sydney Glee Club. The performance includes selections such as Bach's "Jesus, Joy of Man's Desiring"; Handel's "HeShall Feed His Flock" from the Messiah; from The Crucifixion by John Stainer, "God So Loved the World" performed together by the Hampden-Sydney Glee Club and the Farmville State Teacher's College Chorus; and "The Lord's Prayer." WRVA - 61 contains a choral performance by the seventy member Hampden-Sydney Glee Club, with special guests, the Farmville State Teacher's College Glee Club. The performance includes selections such as "Ye Watchers and Ye Holy Ones"; "Lo, Howa Rose ere Blooming"; "O, Holy Night"; and "There is No Death" by Geoffrey O'Hara.

did.unittitle: Virginia Sings: Mary Baldwin College Chapel Choir, 25 May 1951

scopecontent.p: This recording includes commentary and introductions for choral music of the Mary Baldwin College Chapel Choir. It does not include any music. The commentary includes information on the choir group and director, Gordon Page, associate professor of music at Mary Baldwin College.

did.unittitle: Virginia Transportation Crisis, 1986

scopecontent.p: Recording of WRVA's entry in the 1986 Virginia Association of Broadcasters news awards competition for best in-depth reporting. The program documents the efforts of Governor Gerald L. Baliles to pass a multi-million dollar highway improvement program funded through tax increases. Topics include the commission which he named and its hearings and recommendations, the special session of the General Assembly to deal with the issue, various legislators' alternatives and proposals, the position of the Richmond City Council, the proposal and defeat of a state lottery to fund the highway program, and the final revenue proposals that were adopted.

did.unittitle: Virginia War Memorial Dedication, 29 February 1956

scopecontent.p: Recording of the dedication of the Virginia War Memorial in Richmond, Virginia. Includes the reading of a telegram from President Eisenhower, and speeches from Harry F. Byrd, Sr., and General Matthew B. Ridgeway.

did.unittitle: Virginia Weekly, ca. 1953

scopecontent.p: This program includes an interview with Lois Ferguson regarding her husband, Paul F. Watkins, owner, publisher, and editor of the Ashland Herald-Progress from 1933 to his death in 1951. Lois Ferguson is now running the newspaper. Interview also includes information on the history of the Ashland Herald-Progress and the building the newspaper occupies. Program also contains discussions with other staff members of the newspaper.

did.unittitle: Virginia Weekly, 3 March 1956

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Bill Willis and Bill Thompson, this program discusses the honoring of Dr. Robert Woodhouse of Virgina Beach as reported in the Princess Anne Free Press, the slow replacement of coal burning locomotives with Diesel locomotives as reported in the Richlands Press, and the unification of the armed forces becoming a reality at Fort Lee as reported in the Fort Lee Traveller. Also includes the special announcement that Irby Hollans is replacing Willis and Thompson as host of the Virginia Weekly.

did.unittitle: Visit of Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, to Richmond, 11 November 1954

scopecontent.p: Coverage of the visit by Queen Elizabeth (1900-2002), the Queen Mother, to Richmond, Virginia on 11 November 1954. Includes an introduction by Governor Thomas B. Stanley, remarks by Queen Elizabeth, patriotic music by a local school band, and a presentation of a gift by school children for her grandchildren Prince Charles and Princess Anne.

did.unittitle: VPI New President, 4 April 1963

scopecontent.p: Recording of the inauguration of T. Marshall Hahn as president of Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, including speeches by Governor Albertis S. Harrison, United States Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges, and T. Marshall Hahn. Hodges discusses the state of education in the United States and the importance of education in keeping up with rest of the world. Hahn speaks on the challenges of education and his vision for Virginia Polytechnic Institute. This recording is incomplete. The introduction of the speaker Dr. Russell I. Backway(?), Secretary of the National Association of State Universities and Land-grant Colleges is included, but not his speech.

did.unittitle: Washington and Lee Alumni Dinner in Honor of President Francis P. Gaines, 15 January 1959

scopecontent.p: Recording of dinner held at the Commonwealth Club in Richmond in honor of Dr. Francis P. Gaines, president of Washington and Lee University. Dr. Gaines outlines the needs for Washington and Lee to improve as an educational institution. This recording does not include the speech by Governor J. Lindsay Almond, Jr., to which Gaines refers.

did.unittitle: Watch Your Step: Governor's Highway Safety Committee. Program 7, 1948

scopecontent.p: Drama concerning pedestrian safety. Elvira Chewning, crossing the street to her daughter's car after purchasing a cake for her 72nd birthday, is struck by an automobile. The driver had no time to react. Written by J. Sam Fouts. Produced by Ray Kennedy. This recording is track 1 on WRVA - 337A.

did.unittitle: Wildcats, 8 June 1939

scopecontent.p: Transcribed recording of bluegrass performers Clayton McMichen and his Georgia Wildcats. Songs performed are "Pretty Little Widder," "Rose of Shenandoah Valley," "I'm Gonna Learn to Swing," "All Through the Night," "When Mother Prayed for Me," and "Red River Valley." Program is sponsored by Domino Cigarettes.

did.unittitle: William and Mary Honors Convocation, 2 April 1948
did.physdesc: 2 compact discs. Duration: 1 hr., 13 min., 54 sec.

scopecontent.p: Recording of the Honors Convocation at the College of William and Mary on 2 April 1948. The ceremony was dedicated to American-Canadian friendship and includes speeches from Governor William M. Tuck, Prime Minister of Canada Mackenzie King, Governor-General of Canada Viscount Alexander of Tunis, and President Harry S. Truman. Each of these speakers received an honorary degree. Viscount Alexander delivered the principal address. Alden Aaroe, John Tansey, and Walter Bishop reported on the event for WRVA.

did.unittitle: Williamsburg Award Presentation to Winston Churchill, London, 8 December 1955

scopecontent.p: Coverage of the "Williamsburg Award," presented to Winston Churchill in London on 8 December 1955. The coverage was carried live by the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC). The award was presented by Winthrop Rockefeller, chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation. Rockefeller also reads a message from President Dwight Eisenhower. Churchill, the first recipient of the award, follows with his remarks.

did.unittitle: Williamsburg Pageant, 8 April 1953

scopecontent.p: This program features short clips of various colonial-related sounds and music, including a galloping horse, town crier, proceedings of the colonial General Assembly, tolling bells, and organ and other instrumental music. The occasion for the program is not known.

did.unittitle: WRVA 25th Anniversary Forums, October-November 1950
did.physdesc: 3 compact discs. Duration: 2 hrs., 20 min., 10 sec.

scopecontent.p: WRVA 25th Anniversary Forums, sponsored by the Richmond Area University Center, conducted over the course of eight weeks during October and November 1950. Each of the eight forums is approximately fifteen minutes in length, and is devoted to a specific topic - Education, Manufacturing and Marketing, Government and Taxes, Housing, Science, Medicine, Communications, and Engineering. The forums feature a panel discussion between individuals from the Richmond area who are knowledgeable on each topic. The panelists discuss what they believe trends will be in their specific area in the next twenty-five years.

did.unittitle: WRVA 25th Anniversary Religious Service, [November 1950]
did.physdesc: 2 compact discs. Duration: 1 hr., 8 min., 54 sec.

scopecontent.p: Recording of the interfaith religious service held at the Mosque (now the Landmark Theater) in Richmond, Virginia, to mark the 25th anniversary of WRVA. Hosted by Holland R. Wilkinson (1893-1954), this program includes messages by Dr. Theodore F. Adams (1898-1980) of the First Baptist Church, Rabbi Ariel Goldburg of Temple Beth Ahabah, and Monsignor Leo J. Ryan of Sacred Heart Cathedral, and a prayer of rededication by Dr. W. Taliaferro Thompson.

did.unittitle: WRVA 25th Anniversary - To Find Person Born Nearest First Broadcast, 2 November 1950

scopecontent.p: Recording of telephone interview with Tilman Joshua Harrell, a native of North Carolina and the person born nearest to WRVA's first broadcast. He was born on 3 November 1925.

did.unittitle: WRVA 30th Anniversary Cruise Aboard the U.S.S. Tradewind, 25 September-4 October 1955
did.physdesc: 2 compact discs. Duration: 1 hr., 43 min., 3 sec.

scopecontent.p: Coverage of WRVA's 30th anniversary nine-day cruise aboard the U.S.S. Tradewind, bound for Havana and Nassau, from 25 September to 4 October 1955. Featured are music from the ship's band, and comments by an unnamed host who tours the ship, mentions activities, interviews passengers, talks about the progress of the voyage, and talks with the cruise director. Also covered are events in Havana and Nassau, including visiting straw and vegetable markets, going to nightclubs, and attending horse racing.

did.unittitle: WRVA 30th Anniversary Party, 2 November 1955
did.physdesc: 1 compact disc. Duration: 1 hr., 2 min., 17 sec.

scopecontent.p: WRVA 30th Anniversary Party, recorded live in Richmond on 2 November 1955, from the WRVA Theatre. Galen Drake is the host of the event. Included in the festivities is the crowning of Mrs. WRVA by Walter R. Bishop, and contests for free radios, and for couples celebrating their 30th wedding anniversaries, and a baby sweepstakes by Alden Aaroe with the winner announced by C. T. Lucy. There is also a recording by Amos n Andy congratulating the station. Musical performances include "There's No Business Like Show Business," "Sometimes I'm Happy," "Almost Like Being in Love," "Over the Rainbow," and "Love is a Many Splendored Thing." The Acca Temple Shrine Chanters also perform, including their rendition of "Carry Me Back to Old Virginny."

did.unittitle: WRVA 34th Anniversary Promotional Spots, 1959

scopecontent.p: Promotional spots, recorded in 1959, to commemorate the 34th anniversary of WRVA. Included are birthday greetings from U.S. Rep. J. Vaughan Gary, Verbon E. Kemp of the Virginia State Chamber of Commerce, and Reverend A. Purnell Bailey.

did.unittitle: WRVA 35th Anniversary Brochure

scopecontent.p: Advertisements for the anniversary booklet produced by WRVA in celebration of its 35th anniversary. This recording is track 3 on WRVA - 464.

did.unittitle: WRVA 35th Anniversary Celebration: Holiday in Hawaii, 19-25 November 1960

scopecontent.p: Recordings of a series of broadcasts of "Holiday in Hawaii," the trip taken to Hawaii in celebration of WRVA's 35th anniversary. These recordings include Alden Aaroe, the trip's host, interviewing various people going on the trip before departing from Byrd Field, reporting on the flight across the country, discussing the group's arrival in Honolulu, talking with his wife, Edna, about the Kookie-Moo and Hawaiian cloth, and interviewing Mrs. John L. Pulley about her trip to the island of Kauai. Also includes the presentation of gifts representative of Virginia and the reading of a proclamation by Virginia Governor J. Lindsay Almond, Jr., from the oldest state in the Union to the newest state, and the receiving of the proclamation and gifts by the Lieutenant-Governor of Hawaii, James Kimo Kealoha (1908-1985). Lieutenant Governor Kealoha sends thanks to Governor Almond, the people of Virginia, and the trip's participants. The recordings of the presentation of the gifts, the reading of the proclamation by Governor Almond, and Lieutenant Governor Kealoha's statement on WRVA - 459 are duplicated on WRVA - 460.

did.unittitle: WRVA 35th Anniversary: On the Go, 2 November 1960

scopecontent.p: Lon Backman, WRVA broadcaster, interviews some of WRVA's Old Timers - J. Robert (Bob) Beadles, Bertha Hewlett, Walter Bishop, and C. T. Lucy. Bob Beadles discusses his long service with WRVA, the early days of the radio station, and his involvement with the Corn Cob Pipe Club. Bertha Hewlett discusses the various jobs she has held during her long service with WRVA. Walter Bishop discusses WRVA's political coverage and news broadcasts, and expresses his opinion on the 1960 presidential election. C. T. Lucy talks about the beginning of WRVA and his work as an announcer for special events during the station's early years. These recordings contain heavy static. Higher quality recordings of the interviews with Walter R. Bishop and Bertha Hewlett are available on WRVA - 462. This program is track 1-2 on WRVA - 463.

did.unittitle: WRVA 35th Anniversary: On the Go with Bertha Hewlett, 2 November 1960

scopecontent.p: Lon Backman, WRVA broadcaster, interviews Bertha Hewlett, who discusses the various jobs she has held during her long service with WRVA. This recording is track 2 on WRVA - 462.

did.unittitle: WRVA 35th Anniversary: On the Go with Walter Bishop, 2 November 1960

scopecontent.p: Lon Backman, WRVA broadcaster, interviews Walter R. Bishop, who discusses WRVA's political coverage and news broadcasts, and expresses his opinion on the 1960 presidential election. This recording is track 1 on WRVA - 462.

did.unittitle: WRVA 35th Anniversary Program, 2 November 1960

scopecontent.p: Recording of WRVA's 35th Anniversary program. Hosted by Robert Beadles, this program includes the following speeches and music: the Acca Temple Shrine Chanters, directed by Alton Howell, singing "The Winter Song"; greetings from Claude W. Woodward, the Mayor of Richmond, who participated in the inaugural broadcast as a member of the Acca Temple Shrine Chanters; Joseph I. Maust singing "My Wild Irish Rose"; C. T. Lucy, general manager of WRVA, speaking about his thirty-five years service with WRVA and the development of the radio station; William T. Reed, Jr., president of Larus and Brother Company, quoting the remarks his father made on the inaugural broadcast; Holland R. Wilkinson, Charlie Wakefield, and Harold Lawrence, accompanied by Bertha Hewlett on the organ, singing "Have Thine Own Way"; Mrs. Henry P. Garber singing the same song she sung on the inaugural broadcast, "Lack a Rose"; the Sabbath Glee Club, directed by Maurice Williams and including some of the same singers who participated in the inaugural broadcast, singing "Swing Low Sweet Chariot"; Reverend W. Taliaferro Thompson giving a prayer of dedication similar to the one he delivered on the inaugural program; and the Acca Temple Shrine Chanters closing the program by singing "Carry Me Back to Ol' Virginny." Produced by Lou Dean. This recording is track 1-2 on WRVA - 461 and also available as track 4-5 on WRVA - 464.

did.unittitle: WRVA 40th Anniversary Promotional Spots, 1 November 1965

scopecontent.p: Contains various takes of numerous promotional spots, recorded on 1 November 1965, commemorating the 40th anniversary of WRVA.

did.unittitle: WRVA 50th Anniversary Vignettes

scopecontent.p: This recording contains sound clips heard over WRVA of the following events, personalities, and radio programs: the dedication of WRVA's 50,000 watt transmitter in 1939; Adlai Stevenson's concession speech in 1952; a speech by Franklin Delano Roosevelt concerning World War II in 1942; music from the Hit Parade in 1956; Truman announcing the dropping of the atomic bomb on Hiroshima in 1945; Lum 'n' Abner in 1948; The Jack Benny Show in 1949; Art Linkletter's House Party in 1950; The Romance of Helen Trent in 1944; Amos 'n' Andy in 1940; the moon landings in 1969; the Nixon-Kennedy presidential election in 1960; Lou Gehrig's retirement speech in 1938; Jesse Owens winning three gold medals at the 1936 Olympics; Charles Lindbergh successfully flying non-stop over the Atlantic in 1927; the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor and Franklin Delano Roosevelt's declaration of war speech in 1941; Martin Luther King's speech on the step of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D. C. in 1963; the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in 1963; the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy in 1968; the Wizard of Oz in 1939; Alden Aaroe reporting on the tornado that ripped through Monroe Park in 1951; the death of four boys trapped in an abandoned ice box in 1953; Bing Crosby in 1951; Willie Mays in 1951; the marriage of Grace Kelly and Prince Rainier of Monaco in 1956; music clips from 1956 of the Planters, Tennessee Ernie Ford, Nelson Riddle and his Orchestra, Gogi Grant, Elvis Presley, and Morris Stoloff's Orchestra; the first American-manned space flight by Alan B. Shepherd in 1961; Joe Garagiola, Barry Tompkins, Dr. Joyce Brothers, and Edward Newman of NBC congratulating WRVA on fifty years of broadcasting; Sputnik in 1957; Ozzie and Harriet in 1947; and George Hicks reporting first hand on the Normandy invasion in 1944. With the exception of the congratulations from NBC radio personalities, each of these clips is prefaced with the statement, "The year was . . . and Virginians tuned to WRVA to hear . . . " After the clip is played, a narrator lists notable radio programs, popular music, and news events from the same year.

did.unittitle: WRVA 65th Anniversary Gold Show, 3 November 1990
did.physdesc: 3 compact discs. Duration: 2 hrs., 44 min., 30 sec.

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Bob Keeton, this show features three different interviews with Alden Aaroe, Bertha Hewlett, and John Tansey, who offer their reminiscences of the station and people associated with it. The program also includes vintage clips from past shows and commercials. There are musical selections by Johnny Mathis, Patti Page, Nat King Cole, and others. Also featured are calls from listeners who offer their congratulations and recollections.

did.unittitle: WRVA 65th Anniversary Interviews with Hewlett, Aaroe, and Tansey, 1990
did.physdesc: 2 compact discs. Duration: 1 hr., 19 min., 5 sec.

scopecontent.p: Jim Jacobs, WRVA broadcaster, talk with Bertha Hewlett, Alden Aaroe, and John Tansey on his afternoon show. They reminisce about the history of WRVA and their many years of service with the station. This program, interspersed with news, sports, traffic, and weather reports, and commercials, also includes a phone call from Calvin T. Lucy, Jr., and sound clips from early WRVA broadcasts.

did.unittitle: WRVA 65th Anniversary Special with Scott Stevens and Alden Aaroe, 1990
did.physdesc: 3 compact discs. Duration: 2 hrs., 17 min., 53 sec.

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Scott Stevens and Alden Aaroe, this show features calls from listeners offering their congratulations and reminiscences of WRVA, as well as a contest drawing, news, weather, and traffic reports. Stevens plays vintage clips of commercials and previous programs, including a clip from Alden Aaroe Day and a birthday phone call to Aaroe from President Ronald Reagan. There are also interviews with Lou Dean and Tim Farley. The exact date of broadcast is unknown.

did.unittitle: WRVA 65th Anniversary Special with Scott Stevens and Tim Timberlake, 1990
did.physdesc: 3 compact discs. Duration: 2 hrs., 13 min., 24 sec.

scopecontent.p: Hosted by Scott Stevens and Tim Timberlake, this show features calls from listeners offering their congratulations and reminiscences of WRVA, as well as a contest drawing, news, weather, and traffic reports, vintage clips of commercials and previous programs, and an interview with John Harding. The exact date of broadcast is unknown.

did.unittitle: WRVA Dedicatory Program, 23 May 1933

scopecontent.p: Recording of the program broadcast to dedicate WRVA's new studios in the Hotel Richmond, 23 May 1933. Includes music from the Richmond Light Infantry Blues Band, Acca Temple Shrine Chanters, Hotel Richmond Orchestra, and Art Brown, the organist for Byrd Theatre, and speeches by Lieutenant Governor James H. Price and Colonel Thad H. Brown, member of the Federal Radio Commission.

did.unittitle: WRVA History

scopecontent.p: Sounds clips used for WRVA's 50th anniversary album including: Ted Kennedy eulogizing his brother Robert in 1968; George Hicks reporting first hand during the invasion of Normandy in 1944; the announcement of Charles Lindbergh's successful flight across the Atlantic in 1927; Governor Mills E. Godwin, Jr., speaking at the dedication of WRVA's new studios on Church Hill in 1968; Alden Aaroe reporting on the tornado that ripped through Monroe Park in 1951; Bertha Hewlett talking about the early days of WRVA; Pat Binford and the Corn Cob Pipe Club; news reports on the flooding of the James River because of Hurricane Camille; Amos 'n' Andy in 1940; Millard the Mallard; miscellaneous network programs; the opening for the Silver Stars Quartet (9:07-9:46); and Sunshine Sue (Mary Higdon Workman) and the Old Dominion Barn Dance (9:53-15:00).

did.unittitle: WRVA Promotions

scopecontent.p: Contains multiple recordings of two different musical promotions for WRVA Radio. The first set of recordings begin at 0:04 and the second set of recordings begin at 3:18.

did.unittitle: WRVA Radio Tribute to John F. Kennedy, 22 November 1963

scopecontent.p: Part I contains clips of news broadcasts from WRVA and NBC concerning the assassination of President Kennedy. These clips covers the president's condition, the wounding of Governor John Connally, and the arrest of Lee Harvey Oswald. Part II contains clips from a campaign speech Kennedy delivered in Norfolk during the 1960 presidential election and his inaugural address, statements by prominent Virginians, including Governor Harrison and Senators Byrd and Robertson, prayers and eulogies from Richmond's clergy, and a list of meetings canceled because of the assassination. This part also includes interviews WRVA conducted with various people on the streets of Richmond about their feelings on President Kennedy's death.

did.unittitle: WRVA Salute from WBT, 17 March 1939

scopecontent.p: WBT Radio of Charlotte, North Carolina, salutes WRVA for increasing its transmitting power to 50,000 watts. Program includes music from Johnny McAllister, the Texas Rangers, Jane Bartlett, the Golden Gate Jubilee Singers, and Fred Kirby, and a speech from Mayor Ben E. Douglas of Charlotte.

did.unittitle: WRVA Transmitter Dedication Ceremonies, 30 November 1961
did.physdesc: 1 compact disc. Duration: 1 hr., 2 min., 28 sec.

scopecontent.p: Recording of the dedication ceremonies for the new WRVA-AM and FM transmitters, located thirteen miles southeast of Richmond. The program is hosted by Alden Aaroe, and includes the invocation by Reverend Joseph T. Heistand of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Richmond, and remarks by Samuel M. Bemiss (1894-1966), William T. Reed, Jr. (1904-1966), Rosel H. Hyde (1900-1992) of the Federal Communications Commission, and Governor-elect Albertis S. Harrison (1907-1995). The recording also contains remarks by WRVA employees Walter R. Bishop, Jack Clements, and Dick Gillis.

did.unittitle: WRVB Transmitter Tower Completion Program, 6 January 1949

scopecontent.p: Program, 6 January 1949, at the completion of the WRVB transmitter tower. Alden Aaroe reports from the site of the tower. C. T. Lucy, general manager of the Edgeworth Broadcasting Service, is interviewed about the purpose of the tower, cost, use, and the status of the station's application for a television license. The tower's physical characteristics are described, including its height, base, and other construction details.

did.unittitle: Yearender 1963

scopecontent.p: Recording of a presentation of WRVA Radio news entitled, "1963, Year of Contrasts." This program recaps the major stories of 1963 in Virginia, including the establishment of the cities of Virginia Beach and Chesapeake, the white-fringed beetle infestation in Norfolk and the concern over the use of the chemical dieldrin to combat the insect, flooding in Southwest Virginia, the missing University of Richmond students feared drowned during a canoe trip down the James River, WRVA's call for help for the people affected by the floods in Southwest Virginia, drought, Prince Edward County public schools, Richmond and Henrico County annexation, the Southern Christian Leadership Conference held in Richmond, the 24th amendment outlawing the poll tax in federal elections, the purchase of the Richmond Virginians baseball team by a businessman from Manchester, New Hampshire, high school and college sports, and the assassination of President Kennedy. The Prince Edward County public schools segment includes excerpts of statements by Governor Albertis S. Harrison and the Reverend L. Francis Griffin. Governor Harrison responds to criticism of his and the state's inaction in reopening the closed schools by stating that he has no constitutional authority to reopen the schools. Reverend Griffin talks about the opening of the Free School system, the Prince Edward Free School Association, and the impact of the school closings on the children. The Southern Christian Leadership Conference segment includes excerpts of speeches by Martin Luther King, Roy Wilkins of the NAACP, Congressman Adam Clayton Powell, and Dick Gregory. King refers to recent civil rights demonstrations in Birmingham, Alabama, and Danville, Virginia. This program was written by Ed Whitehead and produced by Brick Rider.

did.unittitle: YMCA, [ca. November 1940]

scopecontent.p: This is a recording of the Businessmen's Bible Class of the YMCA. Walter Bishop, the special guest speaker, delivers a speech entitled "Seed Time and Harvest," a lesson provided in celebration of Thanksgiving Day. The program opens with a group sing of "America the Beautiful." The recording ends before Bishop completes delivering his lesson.

did.unittitle: Yoe, John H., Dr., Interview, 28 July 1946

scopecontent.p: Interview with Dr. John H. Yoe, Professor of Chemistry at the University of Virginia, regarding the first atomic bomb test on Bikini Atoll. Yoe discusses his observations after the test, the ship's role during the test, the cruise around the South Pacific, and the impact of naval bombardment on these islands during the war. Interviewed by Lieutenant Commander Walter R. Bishop, WRVA Public Relations director.

did.unittitle: Series XII: Films and Videos
WRVA Dedication, May 29, 1968

scopecontent.p: Film footage of the dedication of WRVA's New Studio on Church Hill. Includes speeches by Governor Mills E. Godwin, W. Brooks George, president of Larus & Brother, and Alden Aaroe. Also includes music by the Bellevue Elementary School Choir. This DVD was created from a 16mm film. A BetacamSP tape was created for preservation.

did.unittitle: Clear Channel Communication, Inc. Employee Tape

scopecontent.p: This video was created to educate employees on Clear Channel's history and mission.

did.unittitle: WRVA

scopecontent.p: This video was created to encourage businesses to advertise over WRVA.

did.unittitle: WRVA/WRVH Sports Radio 910

scopecontent.p: This video was created to encourage businesses to advertise over Sports Radio 910.

did.unittitle: Series XIII: News Tape Morgue, 1 January 1980-31 December 1999.

scopecontent.p: This series contains WRVA local and statewide news reports from 1 January 1980-31 December 1999. Available in digital format upon request. A printed multi-volume chronological inventory by year is available for use in the Library.

did.unittitle: 1 January 1980-22 October 1980.
22 October 1980-19 August 1981.
19 August 1981-7 September 1982.
8 September 1982-31 December 1983.
2 January 1984-20 May 1985.
3 July 1986-28 August 1987.
31 August 1987-13 February 1989.
13 February 1989-2 October 1990.
2 October 1990-23 April 1992.
24 April 1992-28 October 1993.
28 October 1993-17 July 1995.
17 July 1995-31 December 1996.
2 January 1997-21 September 1998.
21 September 1998-31 December 1999.
Series XIV: Special Programs and Airchecks, 1 January 1981-31 December 1994.

scopecontent.p: This series contains snippets of Virginia news reported by WRVA from 1 January 1981 - 31 December 1999. Highlights include election coverage and political activities in the state as well as significant local and statewide events such as floods, snowstorms, hurricanes, fires, major traffic accidents, among others. Also includes occasional in-depth looks at significant newsworthy events and anniversary programs and miscellaneous recordings including AP Award entries, and tribute programs. Series is available in digital format upon request. A printed single-volume chronological inventory to the series is available for use in the Library.

physdesc.extent: 24 cassette tapes and 3 Digital Audio Tapes.
